name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
To clarify: this is a complaint, not a settlement.

The SEC talks a lot about airdrops, but then only seems to argue that distributions via direct sales, bounty programs, and employee compensation are securities transactions.

So, their novel theory on airdrops can't be tested.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Another day, another case of SEC regulation by enforcement.

This time, they say airdrops meet the Howey test's "investment of money" prong, even if no one makes an investment and no money changes hands.

Just remember, SEC settlements are not settled law.
https://t.co/Pt5jsxcYRB

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: Professional success is not a solo sport. That's especially true in legal practice, where you have to attract and represent clients, negotiate with counterparties, advocate to decisionmakers, collaborate with others, etc. This is a team activity. Succeed together or fail alone.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: The best skill many lawyers never learn is how to build good professional relationships. If you want to have a successful career, no matter what success looks like for you, and regardless of how smart or hardworking you are, you have to figure out how to play well with others.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @fubuloubu @RodneyRamsey It's not either/or.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @RodneyRamsey Oh. Yeah. Being effective requires having good relationships or else you get left out and have no ability to influence anything. That's the politics of policymaking 101.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @YohanGGlobal The game is to maximize the ability to impact policy to make it as favorable to crypto as possible. That means maintaining good working relationships with policymakers so they're open to listening & making changes. The nuclear option is a last resort, but always on the table.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Given that the crypto community is organized around a technology based on game theory, it sometimes surprises me how many people have so much trouble understanding how the game of policy advocacy works.

"Just say no to everything always" is a terrible strategy in iterated games.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @BlockEnthusiast There's no one who deserves to be called out imo. Most are hardworking people trying to do their job well, with the hard task of balancing many competing interests and influences. If there's anyone to be concerned about, it's the anti-crypto lobby on the other side (i.e., banks).

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @BlockEnthusiast There are certainly times when bills are drafted entirely outside of Congress and then handed to members for introduction. These usually generate a one-day press hit but don't move forward. More often, outside groups contribute ideas to the Hill, but the drafting is done there.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @BlockEnthusiast Most bills are drafted by legislative counsel working for members of Congress (legislators, not regulators) or for committees. Most legislators who actually know how to get stuff done want to take ownership of their bills, they don't just want text given to them by third parties.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
We can support them when they take positions that promote responsible innovation. We can oppose them when they defend the status quo against progress.

We can enforce the law in the courts if they fail to respect our constitutional rights or their own processes.

We can vote.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Bear in mind that we (the community, the industry) don't have a seat at that table. Only members of Congress do.

We can help them understand crypto's promise & the policies that would most benefit the country. We can make sure they hear the desires of the people they represent.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
If you imagine a scale from 1 to 10 where 1 is absolute crypto-pessimism & 10 is absolute crypto-idealism, you should expect legislation to fall somewhere from 4 to 6.

That's how it always works. Getting to 3 or 7 means one side wields way more power than the other. That's rare.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Policymaking behind the scenes is a hugely complex negotiation among many parties with different goals.

As with most negotiations, striking a deal involves some compromise & leaves most parties feeling less than fully satisfied.

This is how crypto legislation will happen too.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Those well-educated on crypto understand that Terra doesn't represent all stablecoins, Celsius wasn't DeFi, 3AC had nothing to do with the technology, etc.

But as in all things, it's a lot harder to engage with those nuances than to simply say "crypto bad, regulate it to death."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Last week's reports in response to the President's crypto EO were pretty grim. They almost read like a rejection of the idea of decentralization itself.

A lot of crypto policy people think those reports could have looked very different if not for Terra & its ensuing fallout.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
It's hard to overstate the damage that Terra has done to the perception of crypto in DC.

Many policymakers already disliked the notion of a permissionless digital marketplace & wanted to put all of crypto into a well-sealed box.

Terra gave them (un)just cause to push forward.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @bdlatt Love that. One of my favorites, a bit different but closely related: "politics ain't beanbag."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
There are two phrases that capture what it's like to be up close & personal with the policymaking process:

"the art of the possible" ‚Äî you can dream all you want, but if that's all you do, you might as well be asleep.

&

"how the sausage gets made" ‚Äî look, it ain't pretty.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
There's an ideal vision for crypto policy on the one hand, & there's the current political reality on the other.

Effective advocacy requires appreciating & engaging with both.

Ignore the first & you've lost the plot. Ignore the second & you're likely to do more harm than good.

tweet: I'm not an engineer so maybe I'm missing something but it's insane to me that Twitter hasn't figured out how to detect & block scam bots using duplicate profile pictures of verified accounts. I spend half my time on Twitter hiding replies from & blocking fake CZs & Vitaliks.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
In other words, expectation of profit is a feature of all investable commodities, not just securities.

Whether that profit comes in the form of an increase in market price, a staking reward, or any other mechanism should make no difference to the securities analysis.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
...which alone doesn't make the assets into securities.

Expectation of profit is only one of four Howey test prongs & likely the least important for volatile assets (i.e., non-stablecoins).

People hold all kinds of assets with an expectation of profit. Gold, cars, watches, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
The general idea seems to be "if you squint hard enough, staking sort of looks like a dividend or interest, & some actual securities have those, so maybe staked assets are securities too."

That's not how the law works. That just means holders of staked assets expect profit...

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @trustlessexp This argues that ETH was more likely a security *before* the transition to staking & supports the idea that the merge was a significant derisking event.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @provoost Is this serious or satire?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
I'd say I haven't heard a compelling argument as to why staking makes an asset more like a security under the Howey test...

...but actually I haven't heard any argument at all. It's just something people say without regard for either (1) how staking works or (2) what the law is.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Don't base your identity or your financial well-being on the hope that a volatile asset will go up in value.

Look what the last couple years have done to the goldbugs.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
21/ @BlockchainAssn appreciates that committee staff have been so open to dialogue over the last few months.

We're grateful to @SenStabenow, @JohnBoozman, @SenBooker, & @SenJohnThune for their great work & we look forward to discussing ways to fix the issues raised here.

[end]

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
20/ It‚Äôs also worth recognizing the excellent process that Senate Ag has run so far.

Instead of trying to rush something into law quickly (as sometimes happens), the bill‚Äôs sponsors are taking their time to understand the issues. Today's hearing was another solid step forward.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
19/ There are other areas for improvement in the DCCPA as well, but I‚Äôll leave the critique there for now.

Despite these issues, it‚Äôs exciting to see Congress move forward on a crypto bill that gets so much right.

There‚Äôs nothing here that can‚Äôt be fixed with a few good tweaks.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
18/ Fifth, the bill threatens financial privacy by forcing all "digital commodity platforms" to conduct warrantless surveillance under the Bank Secrecy Act.

If you don't know why that's an issue, see @coincenter's lawsuit against the Treasury Department:
https://t.co/Fom8MKwDzP

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
17/ Dodd-Frank gave the CFTC similarly wide extraterritorial jurisdiction for swaps markets & it didn't go well, leading to years of contested rulemaking & litigation.

This could be even worse for crypto, given the inherently global nature of the technology & thus the markets.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
16/ Fourth, the bill gives the CFTC wide extraterritorial jurisdiction, allowing it to regulate transactions that take place entirely outside the United States.

That‚Äôs a mistake. US regulators should focus on US activities & prioritize international cooperation for all the rest.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
15/ ‚Ä¶or custodians that are already licensed & overseen by other prudential regulators.

As I said above, regulation should be tailored to risk. For these brokers, dealers, & custodians, the DCCPA overshoots the mark, requiring registration where it isn't necessary or helpful.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
14/ Third, other ‚Äúdigital commodity platform‚Äù definitions are too broad.

The bill imposes onerous requirements on some firms that aren‚Äôt justified by the minimal degree of risk they pose.

For example, brokers & dealers that only work with large institutional counterparties‚Ä¶

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
13/ To be clear, I'm confident that banning DeFi isn't the goal here.

But it could be an unintended result of applying the same rules to both centralized intermediaries & decentralized protocols.

Regulation should be tailored to risk, but the bill isn't tailored to DeFi at all.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ Similarly, another entity type is a ‚Äúdigital commodity dealer.‚Äù

That definition is also extremely broad: "a person that makes a market in a digital commodity."

Does that mean every liquidity provider in an AMM DEX protocol has to register with the CFTC? That just can't be.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ There‚Äôs a bit more nuance here, but not much.

As @sheila_warren testified, the bill is "unworkable" for DeFi: it says trading facilities ‚Äúshall provide a centralized market for executing transactions.‚Äù

What does that mean for DeFi protocols? Wallets? Apps? Users? Unclear.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ For example, one entity type is a ‚Äúdigital commodity trading facility.‚Äù

The definition goes way beyond custodial exchanges: a ‚Äúgroup of persons that constitutes, maintains, or provides a...system in which multiple participants have the ability to execute...transactions....‚Äù

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ Second, the bill could be interpreted as a ban on DeFi.

The ‚Äúdigital commodity platform‚Äù definitions are all designed for centralized custodial markets. Yet, as @SenGillibrand sharply pointed out, they also might capture DeFi protocols‚Äîno more than code‚Äîwhich can't comply.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ The bill also gives two examples of digital commodities: BTC & ETH.

Yes, we all agree those two are commodities (not securities), but including only those two implies a much narrower jurisdictional scope for the CFTC than it should have & makes an agency turf war more likely.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ The DCCPA‚Äôs digital commodity definition fails to resolve that harmful uncertainty.

The bill has a blanket carveout for "securities," so the SEC can still claim authority over any asset that it wants to accuse of being a security, which under this SEC is basically everything.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ First, the bill‚Äôs ‚Äúdigital commodity‚Äù definition is too narrow & vague.

The biggest unresolved question plaguing crypto now is whether a given asset is a security or commodity. Any legislation on crypto spot regulation must draw a clear dividing line between the CFTC & SEC.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ But, like all early drafts of significant legislation, the DCCPA has some issues that Senate Ag members should address before voting the bill out of committee, or else it might end up doing more harm than good.

Here are the top five issues we see in the current draft:

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ @BlockchainAssn fully supports granting the CFTC exclusive jurisdiction over crypto spot markets & we applaud @SenStabenow, @JohnBoozman, & their talented staff for moving this proposal forward.

For more details on the DCCPA & to read the full text: https://t.co/NFTcqimOrG

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ The DCCPA gives the CFTC authority to regulate trades in a new asset type, a ‚Äúdigital commodity.‚Äù

It also gives the CFTC authority to regulate a new entity category, a ‚Äúdigital commodity platform,‚Äù including:

- brokers
- dealers
- custodians
- trading facilities (exchanges)

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ What is the DCCPA?

The heart of the bill is a grant of exclusive jurisdiction over crypto spot markets to the CFTC.

This reflects a bipartisan, bicameral consensus that the CFTC is the right regulator for crypto. @CFTCBehnam made clear today that the CFTC is up to the task.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ The Senate Agriculture Committee (@SenateAgDems & @SenateAgGOP) held an important hearing today on the Digital Commodities Consumer Protection Act (DCCPA), a bill to regulate crypto spot markets.

It's a good bill, but it needs some work. Here's why. üßµ

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ OFAC may be quickly overwhelmed by a massive number of requests from people who aren't sanctions experts & shouldn't have to hire lawyers or pay legal fees just to get their money back.

The right result is a general authorization for law-abiding US persons to withdraw funds.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ The FAQs acknowledge that US persons should presumptively be granted licenses to recover frozen funds. Good!

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
No one will deny that bad actors have abused crypto.

One benefit of crypto is that frauds & scams are much easier to detect than in traditional finance, so we see when they happen, often in real time.

All a "cop on the beat" has to do is follow @zachxbt to find the bad guys.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
This is not a new problem.

The SEC was famously warned about Enron years before it collapsed, but did nothing to stop it. Same with Madoff. Same with Theranos. Same with many other frauds & scams reported by whistleblowers.

A decent "cop on the beat" doesn't turn & look away.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
The SEC claims to be a "cop on the beat" for crypto. It should be!

But unfortunately, as Jim Chanos puts it, they're more archaeologists than detectives: they wait until things go wrong & then show up to dig for details.

Case in point: ignoring Celsius, but going after BlockFi.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Getting sued is awful. Lawsuits can take over your life & legal fees can bankrupt you fast, even if you did nothing wrong.

The generosity & resolve of crypto folks coming together to crowdfund litigation is amazing, whether @atozy, @PoolTogether_, or otherwise. I love to see it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
This is one of the starkest examples of the Streisand effect I've ever seen in a legal context.

Merits of the case aside, it appears to have drawn way more attention to @atozy's statements than they would've gotten otherwise.

Litigation is a potent weapon, but easily backfires.

name: Jake Chervinsky

Sometimes our views on the importance of civil rights & the extent of protections afforded to those rights by the US Constitution & federal law just don't match up with those of policymakers.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: In the case of US sanctions, it's entirely possible that OFAC misunderstood the nature of the technology, or acted under political pressure, or has information that the rest of us don't, or otherwise made this decision without intending to signal a consequential shift in policy.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
In my view, whenever possible, it's appropriate to give the benefit of the doubt to government officials making these decisions.

We don't know what information or analysis they're acting on. If incomplete or incorrect, our job is to help correct the record, not blindly attack.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Carol_VanCleef @boironattorney @USTreasury EO 13694 specifies eight types of "entities." I'd like to know which one Treasury thinks Tornado Cash is.

It's not clear at all, as you seem to admit by saying "maybe" re: "a new age of...liability for coding." If that's what Treasury meant, they better make it crystal clear.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ovhx65 @USTreasury You're wrong. OFAC's authority here stems from EO 13694, which only allows designation of persons, entities, & their property.

When OFAC designates things like tankers (yachts, aircraft, etc.) it's pursuant to valid authority & in reference to the property of a person or entity.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
This underscores the pandora's box that @USTreasury may have opened by sanctioning autonomous blockchain-based software for the first time.

There's good reason why sanctions have always applied to entities, not technology. Treating Tornado Cash as an "entity" makes little sense.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ The bill looks to improve upon similar proposals for CFTC spot jurisdiction in the DCEA (House Ag) & the RFIA (Lummis-Gillibrand).

Secondary market regulation is a top priority in DC, so don't be surprised if one of these bills (or a combined version) becomes law next year.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ The heart of the bill is a requirement that "digital commodity platforms" like exchanges & brokers register with the CFTC & follow certain rules aimed at protecting consumers, disclosing risks, & preventing manipulation.

Sounds reasonable! Most people are on board with this.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ Four members of the Senate Agriculture Committee just introduced the Digital Commodities Consumer Protection Act, the third bill this year making the CFTC primary regulator for crypto spot markets.

It's a good bill overall & confirms a growing consensus for CFTC regulation.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
We should have rules tailored to digital assets that address concerns about information asymmetry, market integrity, etc. without destroying the unique benefits of decentralization.

But aside from Comm'r Peirce's token safe harbor proposal, the SEC has shown no interest in that.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
The problem is that securities designation under US law is binary: either an asset is a non-security & totally fine, or it's a security & totally prohibited (since compliance is basically impossible).

This shouldn't be "life or death." There should be a reasonable middle ground.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
The mere fact that we spend so much time debating "is [x] a security?" exposes a big failure in US crypto policy.

It makes no sense for a regulatory classification to be so controversial & consequential. It's bad that so many people had to learn something like the "Howey test."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: I hear a lot now from people in DeFi that the strong performance & resilience of DeFi protocols in this downturn feels like validation, & that they're energized about building in the bear market while everything else (bankruptcies, macro, etc.) sorts itself out. This is healthy.

Instead, this appears to be another effort by the SEC to expand its own regulatory authority over crypto markets by enforcement, without doing the hard work of proving that the securities laws apply.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

Maybe that‚Äôs what the SEC hopes you‚Äôll say. Don't.

DOJ charged wire (not securities) fraud. There's no purpose to the SEC piling on...

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

Here‚Äôs CFTC Comm'r @CarolineDPham with a strong statement of the sort you don‚Äôt often see from a leader of one agency to another:
https://t.co/leBHidP3oh

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
16/ That's the same Director who said last November that the SEC doesn‚Äôt engage in regulation by enforcement, even though ‚Äúeveryone in the bar & everybody in the industry believes that that is not accurate & never has been so,‚Äù as one lawyer put it.
https://t.co/A3GdpEFZms

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
15/ This week, the SEC's Enforcement Director testified in Congress & refused to answer some questions for this very reason: confidentiality.

For example, on exchange actions, he said: ‚ÄúI can't talk about what matters we're looking at or not looking at.‚Äù
https://t.co/3Hw1ppzJ4p

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
14/ "...as well as to protect persons against whom unfounded charges may be made or where the SEC determines that enforcement action is not necessary or appropriate." https://t.co/2HSEh1yg5p

The SEC should keep its accusations confidential until & unless it sues the wrongdoer.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
13/ The SEC isn't supposed to act like this, accusing people of breaking the law without bringing an action.

From its website:

"It is the general policy of the SEC to conduct its investigations on a confidential basis to preserve the integrity of its investigative process..."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ It's even worse than that, though.

Some of these assets are currently listed on other trading platforms in the USA. Those platforms now have to wonder if they should delist the assets identified by the SEC to protect themselves from enforcement.

We saw that happen to XRP.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ The individual defendants are now on the hook for litigating the security status of all nine assets & for paying the cost of defending nine separate sub-trials.

The amount of money that would take is astronomical. If I were cynical I'd say that's why the SEC did it this way.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ To win, the SEC must prove that one or more of these assets is a security. In a real sense, these companies are on trial too.

But because the SEC didn't name them as defendants, they aren't allowed to defend themselves in court.

On principle, this is deeply unfair & unjust.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ Despite leveling accusations against uncharged companies in public, the complaint is devoid of legal analysis.

The SEC just makes a few allegations of fact & then summarily concludes that they satisfy Howey.

"But surely these are securities," you say:
https://t.co/WTMuNno0Qs

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ Here, the SEC isn't just accusing the defendants of breaking the law.

The SEC is also accusing ten unrelated, uncharged companies of breaking the law: nine for failure to register digital asset securities & one for operating an unregistered national securities exchange.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ It's not uncommon to learn for the first time that an enforcement agency has identified a violation when a complaint is filed.

But typically, that happens when the agency files an action against the person who they think broke the law.

This is different. Very different.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ As far as I know, the SEC has never addressed these assets before.

We learned the SEC's views on the fact patterns that it believes qualify them as securities for the first time in a federal complaint rather than in guidance or rulemaking.

This is regulation by enforcement.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ The SEC alleges that the defendants committed securities fraud by using material nonpublic information to trade ahead of Coinbase listing announcements.

To establish jurisdiction, the SEC claims that the assets in question ‚Äî nine digital assets ‚Äî are unregistered securities.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ To be clear, I'm not trying to excuse insider trading or fraud in any way. If the allegations are true, these defendants should be held accountable.

But we can & should condemn both the defendants' alleged conduct & the SEC's unjust tactics too.
https://t.co/BlRAY8K6DQ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ Some background.

The defendants are three individuals ‚Äî a former Coinbase employee, his brother, & his friend ‚Äî who allegedly engaged in insider trading.

In addition to the SEC suit, the DOJ indicted them for criminal wire fraud. For more, read here:
https://t.co/8DkvxTUY8J

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ The SEC filed a complaint yesterday accusing ten companies of violating the securities laws: nine digital asset issuers & one exchange.

None of them are defendants in the case. None of them will get their day in court.

If this isn't regulation by enforcement, nothing is üßµ

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

@davidgshort It's normal to include only factual allegations in a complaint.

It's not normal at all to sue one party & include in the complaint a bunch of unproven allegations that *other* parties committed unrelated violations without giving those parties the chance to defend themselves.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @davidgshort This misses the point. Federal agencies aren't supposed to go around accusing people of breaking the law without explaining their rationale & providing due process. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Today is one of those days when I get to remind everyone that:

- complaints filed in court are allegations, not facts
- defendants are presumed innocent until proven guilty
- enforcement agencies can & do get it wrong

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@FreddieRaynolds I agree, in the court of public opinion, if you want to ignore the presumption of innocence, which you shouldn't.

In a court of law, it matters a great deal whether these are securities, regardless whether the person's conduct was wrong.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@TradingPlaces18 (1) You can condemn these defendants' conduct while also condemning the SEC's unfair strategy of trying to set major industry-wide precedent through the backdoor of an insider trading case.

(2) The presumption of innocence is a bedrock principle in the USA. Don't forget it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ErnstBlofield @sergitosergito (1) Innocent until proven guilty.

(2) Even if guilty, exactly as @ernstblofield said, the SEC is making *huge* allegations in this case with major implications for the entire industry. You can condemn insider trading & also separately condemn the SEC's tactics here.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
It's hard to overstate what a mess this will be.

The SEC's jurisdiction turns on whether these assets are, in fact, securities. This means the case may require nine mini-trials, one for each asset, to resolve their security status.

Without the issuers or exchange to defend any.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
The SEC alleges in today's complaint that nine digital assets are securities, but don't explain their analysis for even one.

They also didn't sue the issuers or exchange where the tokens traded: the people with resources to fight back.

They just went after one man & his family.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: "Both consumers and regulators alike will insist on transparency, and the emerging DeFi infrastructure is poised to give it to them."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
The general rule in litigation is that you only file motions to exclude stuff that you think will hurt your case, since otherwise why bother?

So I take this as a sign either that @JohnEDeaton1 has really gotten under the SEC's skin or he has a point to make, or both. Either way.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Don't take this in any way as excusing bad actors who abused crypto. We all agree they should be swiftly prosecuted & punished.

But also, don't mistake their misdeeds in any way as a strike against the technology, which is well on its way to changing the world for the better.

name: Jake Chervinsky

Nothing in the last year has shaken my confidence that crypto will fundamentally reshape the way we transact & coordinate across the world.

Cycles of speculation & correction are a painful but natural part of any major technological shift.

It was always going to look like this.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky

"Bad guys do transactions, so gov't should view everyone's transactions all the time."

We can do better.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Last week, the Office of Government Ethics issued a legal advisory saying gov't employees who own crypto can't work on crypto policy.

It explicitly says an employee who owns $100 of a stablecoin can't work on stablecoin regulation.

This is not a recipe for good policy, folks.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Crypt0Go1d That still feels patriarchal to me, that people are only allowed to make decisions about their own money if they meet some standard of intelligence set by the government, which itself may be biased or unfair. But it definitely sounds better than the wealth test we have in the US!

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
"You can't lose money if you're not allowed to invest in anything risky" is the pernicious but real theory behind many financial regulations.

It's a patriarchal & false concept on the best day, but even harder to justify when the baseline for "no risk" is 9% lost to inflation.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ Yet leadership at the SEC (granted, an independent agency) seems not to care what the President of its own party has directed.

Why?

Theories abound, from failing to understand the industry + technology to prioritizing sheer political ambition. Your guess is as good as mine.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ Why is the SEC acting this way?

I wish I knew. It might be the most-discussed topic in all of crypto policy since it makes so little sense.

Everyone else seems on the same page: follow the President's orders & use the lessons learned to inform smart legislation in Congress.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

I'm guessing, but I expect this means we see new actions filed in the next few months.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

In H2, we may see more proposals, but likely nothing will pass. It's campaign season; everyone's focused on the election.

name: Jake Chervinsky

H2 2022 may be different.

name: Jake Chervinsky

- good news is ignored or spun into bad news
- doomsday predictions get huge engagement

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: The irony of debating regulatory policy to "protect investors" while our central bank's express goal is to make everyone lose money.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
If TradFi asset prices moved this far this fast, do we really think the market structure would survive?

Or would we be discussing bailouts by now?

No doubt, every market has its breaking point & we don't know what'll happen next in crypto. This is a test. So far, we're passing.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
I remember March 2020, when the pandemic crash took down centralized exchanges & threatened to break the immature DeFi ecosystem.

Today, the exchanges are all online & DeFi protocols are smoothly & transparently handling hundreds of millions in liquidations.

This is resilience.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Price corrections are painful, but the big question for crypto is if the market itself stays healthy.

So far it has. It's normal to see high-risk firms punished in these conditions, but the market structure is handling the volatility well.

We've come a long way in a short time.

8/ My deepest thanks to @SenLummis & @SenGillibrand (+ their extremely hard-working staff) for this historic effort.

I & @BlockchainAssn are excited to continue working with both offices to make this bill the best it can be, & then to make it the law of the land.

[end]

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ Perhaps most important of all, it's amazing to see a bipartisan effort like this.

Senators Lummis & Gillibrand are on opposite sides of many political issues in DC, but the fact that they can work together on sensible crypto policy is a *huge* positive sign for the future.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ There's room for improvement, but we're lucky to have great allies in Senators Lummis & Gillibrand. They want to get this right & they're looking for feedback from all of us to make it happen.

Today's a milestone, but only a midpoint in a long process.
https://t.co/Y3sE667PPm

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ The bill provides clarity on many other issues, large & small, to encourage responsible innovation & make sure the US stays a global leader in finance & technology.

A de minimis tax exemption; SEC custody requirements; fair treatment for crypto banking; the list goes on.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ The bill also adopts the McHenry/Ryan proposal to fix the no good, very bad crypto tax provisions introduced by last year's infrastructure bill, which we should strongly support (see below).

Another solid proposal with bipartisan, bicameral support.
https://t.co/zr4ir7IWNA

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ The top highlight in my view is the inclusion of a modified version of the Digital Commodity Exchange Act (DCEA), a bill proposed earlier this year in the House, making the CFTC the primary spot market regulator for crypto.

This proposal now has bipartisan, bicameral support.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ NY had (& still has) a chance to lead the way on crypto broadly & Bitcoin mining specifically.

Good policy here would mean both carrots & sticks: at minimum, an incentive for miners to shift toward renewables is an easy win.

NY's "all stick" policies send a clear message...

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ On matters of policy, I'm a pragmatist.

Good policy requires reality-based thinking: honest analysis of costs & benefits, of opportunities & risks, of first- & second-order effects.

The NY mining ban does none of that. It's a moral victory for a few, detached from reality.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ ...but more likely has a net negative effect by pushing miners to build in places with fewer or no environmental regulations.

"You admit these evil miners don't care about the climate!" the NY wing will say.

Not at all. I'm merely explaining the economics, like them or not.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

It gives a small contingent of NY environmentalists an excuse to blame others for the perceived (but not real) issue of bitcoin's energy use, but that's about all.

At best, it has zero impact on emissions...

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
13/ The result is a decentralized & stable asset at the cost of capital inefficiency: more than $1 in assets for every $1 in stablecoin.

This finally brings us to UST.

It tried to be everything at once: decentralized, stable, & perfectly efficient, using no collateral at all.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ Stablecoins like $DAI are collateralized by other assets like $ETH, but instead of being held by a custodial issuer, assets are held in a non-custodial smart contract on the blockchain.

Since those assets are volatile, overcollateralization is required to maintain stability.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ Decentralized stablecoins consist of autonomous, self-executing protocols running on public blockchains that seek to produce a dollar-pegged token without relying on a trusted third party.

The best-known example is the Ethereum-based MakerDAO protocol & its $DAI stablecoin.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ But not all custodial stablecoins are created equal. They're only as good as their issuer, & not all issuers are so trustworthy & transparent.

One of the main goals of blockchain technology is to disintermediate untrustworthy third parties.

Enter decentralized stablecoins.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ Custodial stablecoins represent the vast majority of total stablecoin volume & are very stable & reliable, provided the issuer is trustworthy & transparent.

The industry standard is @circlepay & its widely-adopted + regulated stablecoin $USDC. There are other solid ones too.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ In general, there are two types of stablecoins: custodial & decentralized.

Custodial stablecoins are issued by a central administrator & backed by collateral held in a bank or other institution. These are usually fully collateralized: $1 in assets for every $1 in stablecoin.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ Stablecoins are a vital innovation with massive promise for advancing US interests at home & abroad.

To strengthen global dollar dominance, promoting stablecoins should be a top national priority. Not to mention the benefits for inclusion, efficiency, competitiveness, & more.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ UST's collapse wrought havoc on the crypto markets, resulting in billions of dollars in lost value.

The question everyone's asking in DC now is: what should policymakers do?

To answer, we first have to step back & consider the stablecoin space as a whole & where UST fits in.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ This mechanism failed.

UST lost its peg, triggering a "death spiral" that caused both UST & LUNA to lose all their value. LUNA went from $80 two weeks ago to ~$0 today.

I'll skip the details of exactly how & why it failed. See the links here for more:
https://t.co/RLBozz4h3P

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ Similarly, it sought to let users redeem $1 of LUNA for 1 UST regardless of UST's market price.

For example, if UST traded at $0.98, arbitrageurs could redeem it for $1 of LUNA, earning $0.02 & pushing up UST's price by reducing its supply. Same in reverse if UST traded > $1.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ Instead of collateral, it used an algorithmic mechanism designed to stabilize UST's price at $1 by incentivizing market forces of supply & demand.

It sought to let users redeem 1 UST for $1 of Terra's native token, LUNA, no matter the price of UST on the secondary market.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ First, a quick summary of what happened:

TerraUSD (UST) was a stablecoin on the Terra blockchain. It aimed to hold a peg to the US dollar, a stable value of $1 per UST.

Unlike most stablecoins, UST was purely algorithmic, meaning it didn't use any collateral to hold its peg.

Similar products still trade to this day.

I don't want to match one logical fallacy with another by drawing a false equivalency here. Algo stables are on a different level from BTC & ETH, literally & figuratively.

But many otherwise smart people have argued that both were doomed by design. Take a beat is all I'm saying.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Ethereum launched in 2015. The DAO hack was in 2016. Doomed for all time?

Bitcoin launched in 2009. The value overflow bug was in 2010. Doomed for all time?

It's good to ask if algo stables simply violate the laws of financial physics by design, but only time & trial will tell.

PoW mining bans are a pointless self-inflicted wound.

This is bad policy defined: killing jobs & tax revenue for nothing but a headline.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
DAOs are supposed to be *different* from corporations.

Like all decentralized systems, they make different tradeoffs, sacrificing efficiency for transparency, inclusion, resilience, etc.

Embrace the tradeoffs or don't bother. Corporations masquerading as DAOs will not survive.

This week marks the three-year anniversary of the last time the SEC provided guidance on whether & when digital assets qualify as securities.

In April 2019, the SEC published a list of non-exclusive factors to consider under the Howey test. Since then, nothing but enforcement.

tweet: @tphillips @ArthurDelaneyHP That's not it. Registration means treating the asset as a security, which (among other unpalatable consequences) would prohibit trading on every venue in the world, a death sentence for assets that derive their utility from their free transferability on public blockchains.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips @ArthurDelaneyHP Issuers would be happy to make all the disclosures in the world if that was all registration required / all the SEC wanted. Unfortunately neither is true. Registration is incompatible with bearer assets on blockchains, & the SEC refuses to pursue a tailored disclosure framework.

tweet: @tphillips @AdamLevitin Fwiw, basically every crypto firm I know would be happy to make disclosures. There's a reason everyone loves Comm'r Peirce's safe harbor. The problem is all the other securities requirements that don't work for crypto: transfer agents, restricted trading venues, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips @AdamLevitin I agree a truly decentralized asset should not require registration, but the SEC more or less claims that all digital assets are "DINO" except for bitcoin. It's hard to interpret that view as anything but a prohibition.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips @AdamLevitin You have it backwards: the question is why *shouldn't* there be a spot Bitcoin ETF? Why shouldn't investors be able to get exposure however they prefer? name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @zooko The rule isn't final yet. People in Europe are mobilizing now to explain to EU policymakers why this is such a big mistake. Hopefully it can be stopped, or at least that the "verification" requirement can be removed, revised, or clarified. TBD.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@zooko This also doesn't get into more complex issues like multisigs or DeFi applications. And even if it works, it's a massive invasion of privacy.

We went through all of this when Secretary Mnuchin proposed a similar rule in the US last year. That didn't even require verification.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @zooko No. An earlier version of the rule only required an attestation, but it was changed to require verification, which is something more (but not clear what). Some exchanges subject to similar rules require a digital signature for verification. Others derisked by blocking entirely.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @zooko You might not be able to withdraw to your own wallet. The rule requires exchanges to "verify" the owner of a wallet but doesn't say how that verification can be done. In other countries with similar rules, this has caused exchanges to simply refuse transactions with wallets.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
20/ Putin could have built crypto infrastructure if he wanted. He didn't. There's no reason to think he will (or could) now.

Here's @NYTimes, which stoked fears about crypto & sanctions evasion last week, on Putin's real strategy. Zero mentions of crypto:
https://t.co/niWQ9VlUIY

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
19/ THIRD: the reality is Putin's spent years trying to sanctions-proof Russia & crypto isn't part of his plan.

His strategy included diversifying Russia's reserves into yuan & gold (not crypto), shifting trade to Asia (not onto blockchains), bringing manufacturing onshore, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
18/ Russia also can't hide its tracks with crypto.

Setting aside valid privacy concerns, the transparency of public ledgers + the analytics capabilities of US forensics firms = crypto is useless for sanctions evasion.

The Treasury Department put it best:
https://t.co/ouzbV6OA8c

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
17/ SECOND: crypto markets are too small, costly, & transparent to be useful for the Russian economy.

Crypto markets are thin to start with, & ruble trading pairs are rare. With Russia cut off from the world's crypto industry, they can't source nearly enough liquidity to matter.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
16/ Can crypto mitigate sanctions by offering an alternative to SWIFT? Not really.

If Russia wants an alternative, they're far more likely to use China's CIPS than a public network they can't control.

Regardless, there's nobody in the free world to do business with them anyway!

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
15/ Crypto works the same way.

US crypto companies offer a variety of services. Russia doesn't get to use them anymore. That's the sanction, just as with all US goods & services.

Russia's ability to use the underlying technology doesn't let them "evade" the sanction in any way.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
14/ Rather, as with primary sanctions, the goal is to deprive Russia of services offered by the free world.

SWIFT is a service. Russia doesn't get to use it anymore. That's the sanction.

Some Russian banks can still do cross-border transfers, they just can't use SWIFT for that.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
13/ What about SWIFT, you ask?

SWIFT is a messaging service that facilitates interbank transactions. Kicking Russian banks off SWIFT will make it harder for them to conduct business.

But it's not the same as "banning Russia from the global financial system," as some have said.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ US persons around the world are cutting ties with Russian SDNs right now, regardless of what payment systems they were using previously.

There's zero reason to think crypto's existence will convince any of them to willfully violate sanctions laws, risking fines & jail time.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ FIRST: Russia's access to a global payment network has nothing to do with the goal of primary sanctions, cutting Russia off from the US economy.

It's illegal for US persons to transact with SDNs, period. It doesn't matter if they use dollars, gold, sea shells, or bitcoin.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ These sanctions have been devastating for Russia so far & will likely be even more effective over time.

But some people are suggesting that crypto could give Russia a way to "evade" or mitigate these sanctions. Is that plausible?

Not at all. I'll give you three reasons why.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ In addition to these sanctions, we've also:

- frozen assets of Russian oligarchs & central bank
- limited Russian banks' access to SWIFT
- banned Russian flights in EU airspace

This list isn't complete & more sanctions are being discussed every day, but you get the idea.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ This brings us to Russia.

The US & our allies have imposed severe sanctions on Russia as punishment for invading Ukraine & to deter further aggression.

These sanctions aren't comprehensive. They're targeted at Putin, his oligarchs, the government, & other state entities.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ To be most effective, US sanctions laws are extremely broad:

- "US person" means every US individual, company, etc. all over the world
- the law prohibits direct & indirect transactions, plus "facilitation"
- violations are strict liability offenses; zero tolerance for errors

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ This is crucial to understanding sanctions policy:

The main goal of US sanctions is to deprive SDNs of access to the US economy by making it illegal for US persons to transact with them.

SDNs can't buy US goods or services, sell products to US markets, own US property, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ OFAC adds targets to the Specially Designated Nationals And Blocked Persons (SDN) List, available here: https://t.co/0wLAMDiwEW

*It is illegal for any US person to transact with any person on the SDN List.*

This is the crux of sanctions: cutting SDNs off from the US economy.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ Here's how US sanctions work:

First, sanctions must be authorized by the President in an executive order or by Congress in legislation.

Second, the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC)  designates specific targets for sanctions: individuals, companies, governments, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ One way for the free world to fight back is by imposing severe economic sanctions on Russia.

Sanctions are a foreign policy tool used to influence the behavior & diminish the capabilities of foreign actors. They seek to deter & punish bad acts through economic consequences.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ To begin, I want to express my strong & unequivocal support for the people of Ukraine fighting a totalitarian invader to defend their homes & their basic rights to liberty & self-sovereignty. Glory to Ukraine üá∫üá¶

The free world must assist Ukraine & fight back against Putin.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ Russia can't & won't use crypto to evade sanctions.

Concerns about crypto's use for sanctions evasion are totally unfounded. They fundamentally misunderstand:

- how sanctions work
- how crypto markets work
- how Putin is actually trying to mitigate sanctions

I'll explain üßµ

Find sanctions compliance counsel & figure this out asap.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

Sanctions don't apply to technology, they apply to people. Sanctions against Russia will automatically cover transactions of all kinds, whether by cash, banks, crypto, or otherwise.

Technology neutrality is the rule.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @bitcoin_eagle @BitcoinIsSaving Credit is not a fiat concept. I can loan you bitcoin, you can promise to pay me back. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @BitcoinIsSaving "All debt is evil" is a pretty insane take tbh, & I'm not here for it. There's nothing wrong with two consenting counterparties deciding to make & take a loan. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @blackdaocrypto @jmflatow It means the user has total control over what information regarding their identity is shared, with whom, & when. Third parties cannot access that information without the user's consent.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

Digital identity is important for a mature decentralized ecosystem for many purposes having nothing to do with surveillance. We need to achieve them ourselves, or else surveillance will become merely a cost of doing business.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

If we onboard enough people to ours, we can effectively resist theirs. This is top priority.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ Rep. Gottheimer's bill is the first really good proposal we've seen, but perhaps not the last.

On the other side of Congress, @SenToomey is working on his own bill, & given how great he's been on crypto, I'm very excited to see what he comes up with.
https://t.co/oI86NPAlQ9

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ The opt-in model is important for DeFi stablecoins that use crypto-collateralized or algorithmic mechanisms, which would be unaffected.

This is exactly the right approach: addressing risks we understand now without creating a regulatory moat for some at the expense of others.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ Two features of the bill deserve added praise:

- it explicitly allows nonbanks to issue stablecoins

- it uses an opt-in model, so issuers who want to take advantage of it can, but none are forced to

This strikes a great balance between mitigating risk & enabling innovation.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ Qualified stablecoins would be supervised by the OCC, subject to collateral restrictions, & required to have insurance.

The benefit of bearing those compliance costs: qualified stablecoins would be exempt from regulation as securities by the SEC or derivatives by the CFTC. ‚úÖ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ Which brings us to @RepJoshG's draft bill published yesterday, not only the best we've seen, but really quite good. Let me explain why:

The bill creates a new regulatory classification for "qualified stablecoins" that meet certain minimum standards of safety & soundness.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ ...rather than revisiting old ones, which is a good sign, because none of those were reasonable options.

For example, you might remember the STABLE Act from late 2020, which said all stablecoin issuers had to get a bank charter. I haven't heard anyone mention it this year. üëç

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ So now Congress is focused on stablecoins, holding two hearings in the last two weeks.

As is becoming typical, House Financial Services was constructive & positive while Senate Banking was more hostile (with exceptions, as you'll see below).

They're also writing new bills...

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ The PWG report said a few noteworthy things.

It said all stablecoin issuers should be insured depository institutions (read: banks), which is a very bad idea.

But it also suggested that federal agencies lack authority to regulate stablecoins & said Congress must take action.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Whistleblowers take great personal risk to do the right thing & report violations to government.

They risk retaliation & often have to spend out of pocket to hire lawyers to file complaints effectively.

It's about time for agencies to take these whistleblowers more seriously.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Often after massive frauds & scams are revealed, we learn that regulatory agencies were tipped off by whistleblowers far in advance, & yet did nothing.

This was the case for Enron, Madoff, Theranos, & many others.

Yet still today, way too many complaints go un-investigated.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
When I was in private practice, I helped clients submit whistleblower complaints to federal agencies about serious violations that deserved attention.

Unfortunately, these mostly go into a black hole.

Agencies should focus more on whistleblowers & less on harassing good actors.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Nobody hates crypto scammers more than us. Nobody who cares about this tech wants to see criminals use it to get away with defrauding victims.

There's nothing we'd like more than for regulators to protect investors by getting the bad guys.

I wish more resources went to this.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
The amazing thing about crypto, unlike the traditional financial system, is that frauds & scams are transparent & observable by everyone.

We see them happening in real-time. Within hours, the crypto community does investigations that would take law enforcement years (for free).

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Most crypto policy issues are complicated by how fast the tech is growing & changing. It's hard to craft specific solutions with any confidence they'll make sense in a few years.

The best thing regulators can do now is go after the *actual* bad actors: the frauds & scammers.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@tphillips I vehemently disagree about software developers being required to register code. Aside from the 1A issues, this just doesn't make sense. Financial institutions use Excel all over the world; should Microsoft register it as a securities exchange?

Same, but fun chat, as always. ‚úåÔ∏è

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips No worries. I think you're underselling the value of rulemaking though. I agree it doesn't provide quite as much certainty as case law, but waiting for the courts to sort it out is letting perfect be the enemy of good, imo. I'd rather have 80% in 3 years than wait for 100% in 30.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips A few reasons, but primarily because of technical scaling issues: it isn't possible to run central limit order books (CLOBs) on-chain. But in recent years we've also seen the rise of decentralized exchange protocols using automated market makers (AMMs) instead of CLOBs.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips Lots to say on the securities topic. The point of crypto is to allow self-custody & peer-to-peer transactions. Even if disclosures are appropriate to handle info asymmetry, the benefits & risks are materially different in other ways, for which traditional rules don't make sense.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips Ambiguity is inherent in the law, but absolutely not in a regulator's enforcement strategy. Certainty is crucial to business & essential to rule of law. It's the main reason for the success of the US economy & capital markets. "Let the courts sort it out" is simply bad policy.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips It's regulation by enforcement when there's reasonable disagreement about what "the law as written" means & nobody knows what the regulator thinks until a complaint is filed, i.e., when we literally find out what the regulation is supposed to mean through an enforcement action.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips Custodial wallet providers are regulated as money transmitters, not securities intermediaries. Yet again, the question is if the assets in custody are securities or not. The problem is where the securities laws *mandate* using a transfer agent. That doesn't make sense for crypto.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@tphillips It gets stickier with many of the other '33 & '34 Act obligations & restrictions that don't make sense for crypto, like transfer agents, limits on number of holders, etc.

That's where we need policymakers to work with us on good solutions, instead of regulating by enforcement.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips This is very sensible. The underlying concept of Howey is valid in the crypto context (as in all contexts; that's sort of the point). Its application is still uncertain, but again, that's how all principles-based standards work. I'm in favor of tailored disclosure requirements.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @_deathdisco_ I respectfully but strongly disagree.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Mavis60181391 It's not "us vs. them" in the sense that most of "them" are still learning & deciding what they think of crypto & how to handle it.

But some of "them," although a small minority, have decided to stake out a position as antagonists. There have to be consequences for that mistake.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @BigLifer It's both, really. There's still a lot of educating we need to do for the folks who don't get it yet. But for those who do & have simply decided they're against, we need to make sure they feel the full weight of their mistake.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips Hard to argue with the way you've phrased it. "Crypto securities" should definitely be treated like traditional securities. The (unanswered) question is which digital assets are actually "crypto securities" & which aren't. I thought we had a good chat about that a few weeks ago.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@JoelKatz That's fair. It's hard to argue this in the abstract & we're way down the path of hypotheticals already.

I certainly agree that a scheme in which the creator or early investors use deception to trick & profit at the expense of later investors is properly termed a "scam."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@JoelKatz That's not an accurate definition of a Ponzi scheme.
https://t.co/tlcFWoifuA

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @JoelKatz There's an interesting conversation to be had here -- I'd say if there's no deception, there's no fraud & thus no scam (in fact, your description applies to many collectibles that are not viewed as scams) -- but this is off-topic of the point I'm making re: "ponzi" specifically.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@JoelKatz Okay. My view is that "utility" is neither necessary nor sufficient to make an asset not a "scam," although it is certainly relevant.

I view "scam" as synonymous with "fraud." Ponzi schemes are a subset of these: a particular type of fraud, & not the type you're referring to.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@francorioni @JoelKatz I refer you back to the OP.

Your problem is with the dictionary (& 100 years of history around this term), not with me.

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @FreddieRaynolds That's pretty close. An important distinction, because fraud requires intent.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @0xsadcat Fraud is literally in the dictionary definition of "Ponzi scheme." It's named after Charles Ponzi, a convicted criminal who defrauded investors in 1920. The term has been synonymous with fraud for 100 years. Sorry, but I'm not the one trying to redefine the word.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @nik_tchouparov @nicksdjohnson But all Ponzis are fraud by definition, & using the term "Ponzi" to describe an investment (even a very stupid one) absent fraud is inaccurate & unhelpful.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @dcanellis Fair point, I hear you. I just don't think being inaccurate is a good solution.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @cryptosteveo97 You're missing an important element of a Ponzi, though: a central operator who deceives investors by pretending that returns are generated from a legitimate source, in order to continue perpetrating the fraud.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@NewNetNinja That's not a Ponzi.

Ponzi = fraud. End of story.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @dcanellis I don't know anything about SafeMoon, but there are all kinds of terrible investments in the world that don't involve fraud or warrant criminal prosecution. It's important to distinguish between them.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@dcanellis No, actually don't.

Charles Ponzi was a criminal. His name is synonymous with fraud. Why in the world would we want to use his name for branding? üò£

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
You're using the term "ponzi" to mean an economic game with built-in investing incentives & high risk of implosion.

When regulators hear "ponzi" they think it means a fraudulent scheme in which a criminal deceives victims to steal their money.

This term is doing massive damage.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
A crucial element of effective policy advocacy is knowing where in gov't to raise a given issue.

We spend a lot of time with legislators & regulators, all time well-spent, but often at the expense of our third branch: the judiciary.

Sometimes, the answer resides in the courts.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
There's a common view that US law is more restrictive & less welcoming to crypto than other jurisdictions, but that view ignores the strong individual rights protected by the US Constitution.

The Fourth Amendment makes the US the best place in the world for crypto. Here's why üëá

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @nadnerb217 @CashflowREAM Fair point. I just don't see these as technological upgrades on existing systems, but rather brand new concepts that create unique issues not dealt with before by previous regulators. I don't see anything in crypto like that. The tech is new, but the substantive issues are not.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @CashflowREAM I'm not a fan. Crypto is a technological upgrade on the existing system. We don't create new regulators every time technology changes; we expect the regulators that already handle the existing system to adapt to the new one. I don't see why we'd treat crypto any differently.

It also means critiques of Web3 that assume its end state will look anything like its current iteration will be laughable in 12 months.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ No matter what, we have some big policy issues to sort out for crypto's future.

Ideally, we do that by a thoughtful process, not by rushed regulation or enforcement to pop a bubble.

In that sense, the short-term pain of a bear market could support long-term progress.

[end]

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ So from a regulatory perspective, it wouldn't be the worst thing if the market cooled off for a while.

Lower prices & less volume = fewer retail participants + reduced systemic role = less risk = fewer members of Congress saying "regulators do something" = room to breathe.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ Regulators are definitely starting to see the genuine value & potential in crypto.

But they have more important things to do in 2022 than figure out how to redefine the whole body of financial regulation for a decentralized ecosystem.

This just isn't top priority right now.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ True or not, the SEC is largely credited in DC with ending the 2017 bubble via aggressive investigation & enforcement.

This is one theory that might explain the SEC's otherwise inscrutable approach in 2022. It's not about coherent regulation, it's about crushing the market.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: 6/ Put all this in the context of global monetary & fiscal instability due to covid, rising geopolitical tension, & a growing domestic partisan divide, & it's easy to see why regulators want to get a handle on crypto, which to them looks like the embodiment of 2022 irrationality.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ Regulators also didn't have reason to fear systemic risk in 2017 & could be pretty confident in their ability to manage the impact.

2022 looks different, due to the presence of DEXs & (far more importantly) massive expansion in stablecoin volume. Stablecoins are a *big* deal.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ Can you really blame them?

The bull market kicked off with "degens" farming food tokens in mid-2020. Fast forward through 18 months & billions of dollars of speculation in dog money & jpegs, not to mention hacks & rug pulls, & you can see where regulators are coming from.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ They're particularly concerned because of how much retail participation they see in the 2022 edition.

With a few exceptions (like Katy Perry's crypto claws), the 2017 bubble didn't really breach the mainstream before it blew up.

This one has spread everywhere & keeps going.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ Regulators looking at the crypto market over the last 12-18 months see a high-risk speculative mania inflated by unrealistic or even false promises.

They assume it will end badly for most participants just like it did after the 2017 ICO bubble & they want to limit the damage.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ A small silver lining of a crypto bear market is that it may relieve some regulatory pressure.

For good reason, regulators with limited resources focus attention on issues with widespread impact & systemic importance.

To a degree, shrinking markets = lower risk = less focus.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips SEC hasn't given guidance since April 2019. Even then, all we got was a non-exhaustive list of 60+ factors to consider with no context for how to prioritize them. Before that, we had guidance from Dir. Hinman, which Chair Gensler may not stand by. This is all far from sufficient.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips The SEC's view may not have legal weight, but it does cause serious harm to enforcement targets, including American companies trying to do business in good faith. This is why agencies are supposed to follow ethics of business prosecution & why guidance should precede enforcement.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips It's not called *rulemaking* by enforcement.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tphillips You're wrong on this. The industry has hired hundreds of top-notch securities lawyers for years & the overwhelming consensus is that the law is *not* clear. Regulation by enforcement is when an agency reveals its views in a complaint rather than guidance. The SEC must do better.

tweet: My job isn't just to advocate for good crypto policy, but also to let you know where the regulatory winds are blowing & how to maximize our chances of long-term success, i.e., building systems that policymakers embrace. This may feel like tough love sometimes, but it's important.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
I suspect some DeFi devs have "finish decentralizing" vaguely on their roadmap, but no concrete plans for next steps.

Instead, they feel pressure from a competitive market (& maybe from their investors) to keep shipping new features instead.

Stop this now, or live to regret it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @milesjennings @boironattorney The risk of non-compliance flows overwhelmingly from points of centralization in the DeFi ecosystem. The best way to achieve compliance is to eliminate them. That's the entire point of DeFi.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @milesjennings @boironattorney I don't understand where you're coming from here, tbh. "Decentralized" is literally in the name. The point of the technology is to disintermediate single points of failure, which centralized front-ends are. Why on earth would we *not* build decentralized front-ends?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @milesjennings You're missing the point. Front-ends can be both decentralized & compliant. To effectively argue to policymakers that DeFi isn't "decentralized in name only" & doesn't require the same level of regulation b/c it doesn't pose the same risks, decentralized front-ends are a must.

Hosted interfaces are common, & are controlled by a single operator that can collect sensitive data, deny access, etc. DeFi needs to transition away from this.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Brett_FTXUS Understood, & of course nobody knows where we'll end up long-term. All I mean is, as a strategic matter (not just a normative one), this isn't the time to compromise on our core principles. For now, Sec. Yellen says she's happy with current guidance. Let's see what happens next.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Brett_FTXUS So what we need is not a tailored KYC obligation that re-intermediates a system designed for the explicit purpose of disintermediation.

Instead, we need to rethink the AML regime & build new mechanisms to achieve our shared underlying policy goals without KYC. Tough, but doable.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Brett_FTXUS ...but there's no such thing as KYC that preserves anonymity.

KYC by definition means a central intermediary "knows their customers" & surveils transactions. That's not how DeFi works. If it were, then DeFi wouldn't be decentralized at all, & could be run on an ordinary server.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Brett_FTXUS I don't think KYC is holding DeFi back from "banking the unbanked" at all. If anything, the opposite: imposing traditional KYC requirements would exclude the same unbanked from this new financial system who have been excluded from TradFi all along.

Yes, tailoring is necessary...

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Brett_FTXUS I get where you're coming from & appreciate the desire for regulatory clarity ASAP, but this isn't a compromise we can accept. "Permissioned DeFi" is an oxymoron; there's no point to using a blockchain if a single entity has total control over access.
https://t.co/Wmmhu193pW

There is *not* a fine line between offering a risky but legitimate investment opportunity & a ponzi scheme. There's a gaping chasm.

We should protect the rights of entrepreneurs to engage in the former. We should prosecute people who engage in the latter.

Don't confuse the two.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Incorrect overuse of the term "ponzi" is a huge messaging blunder.

The term refers to a fraudulent scheme in which a central operator deceives victims with false promises of investment returns to steal their money.

We aren't going to "take it back" & it makes crypto look bad.

Also none of this is meant as legal advice. If you want to fractionalize NFTs, get a lawyer!

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@jerrybrito Your point about fractional shares of high-price physical items is on-point.

But just because these vehicles issue securities from a Delaware LLC doesn't mean we should have to do it like that. Maybe it's just the most efficient way to do it in TradFi (sad). We can do it better.

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@jerrybrito I think we're in full agreement up to that point.

Where we may differ is in the weighting of those facts & circumstances. I'd emphasize case law saying efforts must be "essential" to trigger Howey, & focusing on promises made by central actors to create an expectation of profit.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@jerrybrito If the DAO promises to do more than just pool capital to buy & fractionalize the NFT, it gets complicated. We have to do a bunch of facts & circumstances analysis.

Who are the DAO's leaders? What efforts did they promise? Are those efforts managerial or entrepreneurial?....

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@jerrybrito On DAOs that buy & fractionalize NFTs, I also don't think the securities laws should apply, for the reasons you explained in your ConstitutionDAO post: https://t.co/KN9eVAbanV

If jointly owning a commodity isn't a security, then pooling capital to do so shouldn't be either.

If you're following Grayscale's application to convert GBTC to an ETF, here are the SEC's deadlines:

12/23: approve, deny, or delay
2/6: approve, deny, or state grounds for disapproval & seek more public comment
5/7: approve, deny, or delay
7/6: final deadline to approve or deny

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Crypto has always relied on its supporters to educate & onboard newcomers. Like all the best things we do, our approach to sharing information is decentralized.

Let me know how these discussions go & what tips you have to get the message across. Have a great holiday season! üéÜ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10: Don't take it personally.

No matter what, some of our family will angrily accuse us of various & sundry offenses: boiling the oceans, enriching criminals, buying tulips, etc.

Know this: it's not you, it's them. Breath deep & remember, your crypto family is here for you üíï

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9: Know when to move on.

You spend tons of time consuming crypto content. Your family probably doesn't. Don't try to go all the way down the rabbit hole at once (unless they want to).

If you can, just make a positive impression & pique your family's curiosity, then let it go.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8: Acknowledge uncertainty.

People can sense a weak argument when presented as an absolute certainty with no drawbacks or downsides; it just doesn't pass "the smell test."

Be honest about the risks, the unsolved issues, & the unknowns. Don't act like you can predict the future.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7: Seek common ground.

This is the art of persuasion 101. If you treat any discussion as an argument, you'll most likely end up with two opposing sides. If you want to reach consensus, find common ground & build from there.

Learn to use Rapoport's Rules:
https://t.co/votKV2n6GI

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6: Listen more, talk less.

Often, the best way to break through to people is to get them thinking for themselves. One good question can be more effective than hours of explanation.

Resist the urge to simply repeat the same old talking points. Ask questions, listen, & ask more.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5: Know your audience.

Crypto touches so many different facets of life. Because of that, there are many social, economic, & geopolitical points to be made in its favor.

Think about which are most likely to resonate with your family members, & then speak to what they care about.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4: Keep it simple.

Remember how hard it was to understand crypto at first? Put yourself back in that mindset.

Don't try to explain technical details or advanced concepts. Avoid jargon & name-dropping. Stick to the basics. Go slow. Focus on the big picture & share your passion.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3: Come prepared.

If you expect questions on crypto, take time in advance to think about or research how you want to respond.

We all know the feeling of looking back on conversations with family & wishing we'd said something different or better. Try to do that work beforehand.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2: Avoid financial advice.

You should always be careful about telling family what to do with money, & that goes twice for crypto.

Even with "blue chip" assets, the volatility alone can be too much for some people. Being blamed for family losing money is a worst case scenario.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1: Skip the hard sell.

Nothing turns people off faster than an aggressive pitch, especially when they're trying to relax over the holidays.

If your family wants to talk about crypto, great. If not, great. Don't force it. You'll only make them more closed-minded if you're pushy.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

You know what that means: questions from family members who are curious about crypto, or skeptical, or downright hostile.

Are you expecting questions like these? Here are 10 tips I've learned for answering them effectively üßµ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@nullpackets @boironattorney Ideally, we look to the underlying policy goals of the securities laws: closing information gaps b/w asset issuers & holders.

If the issuer made promises leading to the expectation, it may be valid to require the issuer to make disclosures backing up those promises. If not, not.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @boironattorney @nullpackets But also the test isn't for *any* expectation of profit, it's for a *reasonable* expectation of profit, & case law primarily looks at whether the issuer/promoter made promises leading to that expectation. Query whether CT's ape reflex qualifies as "reasonable" as a matter of law.
