14/ Then today, a bipartisan group led by @PatrickMcHenry & @RepTimRyan (plus @RepTomEmmer, @RepDarrenSoto, @WarrenDavidson, @RoKhanna, @RepTedBudd, @RepSwalwell, @RepAGonzalez, & @RepKevinBrady) proposed a comprehensive fix.

This is the one, you guys! üî•
https://t.co/OCZC4P6vCg

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
13/ That brings us to the House, where the real action is.

To start, 10 Democratic members led by @RepDarrenSoto & @RepRoKhanna wrote a letter to @SpeakerPelosi on Monday urging her to promote innovation & support a fix.

The letter is great. Read here:
https://t.co/rXaLLYrQ6L

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ On the other end of the spectrum, @TedCruz introduced a bill Tuesday to repeal the tax provisions entirely. Perfect, right?

Sadly, no. No matter how much we like this bill, the political reality is Congress won't pass it & the President won't sign it.
https://t.co/Owy6TYRJDx

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ Senators Lummis & Wyden were our champions back then, & we owe them a debt of gratitude.

Yet, in my view, although this language was the best we could do in a bad situation, it isn't ideal.

I'd rather not settle for a rule of construction now. Let's try to do this right.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ In the Senate, @SenLummis & @RonWyden introduced a bill on Monday that looks a lot like the compromise amendment we rallied for in August.

It doesn't change the bill's bad language. Rather, it adds a "rule of construction" to narrow the bill's scope.
https://t.co/BZiDRPHC0b

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ Thankfully, many members of Congress agree.

A large, bipartisan group understands that the bill is unworkable in its current form & are dedicated to crafting a legislative solution. A lot has happened already just this week.

Here's where we stand in both the House & Senate:

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ The bill also massively expands the government‚Äôs warrantless surveillance regime, places an unacceptable burden on the right to privacy, & creates unnecessary new cybersecurity risks by exposing sensitive information to a potential data breach.

This is bad policy, full stop.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ To be clear, everyone in the crypto industry agrees that folks should pay whatever taxes they owe.

Our objection is that the bill treats everyone‚Äîeven small businesses‚Äîas if they were financial institutions, & imposes obligations for which compliance is literally impossible.

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ The digital asset definition reads:

‚Äúany digital representation of value...recorded on a cryptographically secured distributed ledger or any similar technology as specified by the Secretary.‚Äù

That is, anything on a blockchain, no matter if reporting it makes sense or not.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ The broker definition reads:

‚Äúany person who (for consideration) is responsible for regularly providing any service effectuating transfers of digital assets on behalf of another person.‚Äù

This is wildly overbroad & vague. Who does this even apply to? Can you tell? I can't.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ The bill has three main flaws:

- the broker definition, which could force nearly everyone in crypto to do tax reporting
- the digital asset definition, which could apply to anything on a blockchain
- the cash transaction report expansion, which is the infamous 6050I provision

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ As a reminder, the infrastructure bill imposed tax reporting requirements on an unknown but possibly massive number of actors in crypto, even where compliance is impossible.

This could include miners, validators, software developers, wallet providers, NFT creators, & more.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ üö® A full update on the infrastructure bill:

President Biden signed the bill into law on Monday. The crypto tax provisions are officially set to take effect on January 1, 2024 (for FY2023 reporting).

Several members of Congress have already proposed new bills to fix this üëá

name: Jake Chervinsky

10/ Finally, as part of representing the industry in DC, I also hope to represent *you*‚Äîthe users, the builders, the folks who care deeply about how this all unfolds.

Our community is our strength. We have to do this together. It's the only way.

(But I'm still not your lawyer.)

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ So, now what?

I won't lie: we've got our work cut out for us. We have some big problems to triage (like the infrastructure bill), some new challenges to defend against, & many many policymakers to educate.

It's also time for us to go on offense. More on that soon, I promise.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

Dave is a DC veteran with a record of excellence & a passion for crypto, & he knows how to get things done. The crypto lobby is leveling up:
https://t.co/f989GmQ2Fk

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ I'm genuinely fired up about focusing my time & energy on this mission.

In case you don't know, I'm a true believer in Bitcoin & the entire crypto movement. I spent a long time diving deep on DeFi, but now I'm excited to broaden my scope & represent the entire industry in DC.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ Over the last few years, I've had the pleasure of working with BA on many policy issues in my role as @compoundfinance GC.

So when Kristin & I began discussing this job‚Äîbuilding out & running the industry's legal & policy function in DC‚ÄîI had zero doubt. This is why I'm here.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ It's time for us to take charge of this debate, & @blockchainassn is leading the way as the unified voice for the crypto industry.

BA's membership includes top companies from every corner of industry, an unparalleled chief in @kmsmithdc, & a highly skilled & passionate staff.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ ...like many disruptive technologies, crypto presents a major challenge to the status quo.

Many of the legal & regulatory frameworks governing legacy institutions aren't a good fit for the new digital world we're building.

Yet, public policy has been painfully slow to adapt.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ As always, success brings attention, & lately the crypto industry has gotten more than its fair share of attention from regulators & policymakers.

In general, that's good & healthy: it shows government recognition that crypto is here to stay & must be taken seriously.

But...

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ Crypto took the world by storm in 2021.

Bitcoin is legal tender. DeFi is a nine-figure sector. NFTs are on every magazine cover. Web3 has tech giants struggling to keep up.

At this point, it's impossible to deny crypto's geopolitical, macroeconomic, & cultural significance.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ I'm excited to announce my new role as Head of Policy for @blockchainassn, the crypto industry's premier trade group in DC.

My sole focus will be crafting & advancing good crypto policy in the USA & abroad. This is our main challenge now. I'm all in.

Why BA & what's next üëá

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
To close out this stream of thought:

I expect the next few years will be the most important in the history of crypto policy, before or after. It's up to us to create the future we want for the world. Nobody will do it for us.

We will prevail.

I'll have news next week.

[end]

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Those challenges will come in many forms, but the only one that truly worries me is the time-tested strategy of divide & conquer.

The outrage machine has turned its eye toward us. We can't fall for it, we can't feed it.

We have to stay focused. We have to be patient.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
So, here's my ask:

Let's all recognize that we're in uncharted waters, that we're trying to do something big here, that the challenges are great, that we'll make mistakes, but at the end of the day, we'll do it all together.

We'll prevail together. There's simply no other way.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
To press that advantage, we'll need to conduct much of our government affairs campaign in public.

That means learning how to communicate, how to work together, how to speak with one voice. Nobody's ever done this before on the scale we need to. It'll be tough.

It's inevitable.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
One of our huge advantages is our ability to coordinate online. We're digitally native: this makes us fast, broad, & effective in a way few other movements have been.

It's the same reason Bitcoin took off in the first place; the same reason everything we're doing has momentum.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @ChoiceThoery Frustrating day of responding to people who just learned about the crypto lobby & are here to fix it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
But when I say "we will prevail," as I often do in the course of explaining some enforcement action or proposed legislation or whatever, I mean it.

It won't be easy, there'll be hard days, & I don't know exactly what path we'll take to get through. But we will.

It's inevitable.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Evanish @JpCortez27 All of these things are being done. My only point was to explain to the community that we aren't spending political capital on fighting this week, so don't whip yourselves into a frenzy over call-bombing the House, after many people asked "do we need to call our reps."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Evanish @JpCortez27 If you think I don't get how bad this could be, you aren't paying attention & are wasting my time.

But if you think we could change the bill now, or that the fight is over because of a vote this week, then you don't understand government affairs or administrative law.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Evanish @JpCortez27 But the *reality* is that spending political capital today fighting a bill that might not pass anyway is completely stupid. This is both common sense & grassroots organizing 101. What's your idea? We should plan a million-man march on DC for every vote on a bad crypto bill?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Evanish @JpCortez27 I am being very realistic. The bill is bad. I spent countless days & nights without sleep fighting it in August. I explained to everyone on here how bad it was. I went on podcasts to tell the story of the entire saga. I started out my thread today saying how bad it still is.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Evanish @JpCortez27 What's your goal here? Want me to say how completely awful everything is? Or are you just having fun trolling?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Evanish It's called deregulation. Maybe you've heard of it. Very popular in recent years, including legislative rollbacks to Dodd-Frank in 2018.

Anyway, it seems like you're more interested in complaining than helping? Or do you have some brilliant idea for what we should be doing?

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Evanish Legislation gets repealed or amended *all the time* from one Congress to the next, particularly when control between parties changes.

That's also one of many options we have, & not the most likely one to succeed. This goes to rulemaking next. The courts after that, if need be.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Evanish We had a bipartisan group of Senators give floor statements qualifying the crypto provisions. That matters. It was a huge win & unique to us.

We're viewed very differently now. The coverage in mainstream media, the money flowing in, the rising interest among policymakers, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Evanish There's a huge difference between wearing rose-colored glasses & understanding political reality / the basics of grassroots organizing 101.

I think we agree in general, though.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Evanish Public policy advocacy isn't so black & white as you suggest. Before the infrastructure bill debate, the crypto lobby wasn't taken seriously. Now we are, in a big way. Don't miss the forest for the trees & don't discount our chances of walking this back. Two years is forever.

But the crypto lobby has to be smart enough to pick & choose its battles; to fight those we can win, or when the benefits of the L outweigh the costs. That's why you don't see a call to arms now.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ But there's no fight to be had today that's worth spending the ammunition.

Regardless, I'm as optimistic as ever that ultimately good policy will prevail. We have the best people on our side (like @abesutherland, a one-man army on 6050I).

For now, keep calm, carry on.

[end]

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ There's a long road ahead, including 2022 midterm elections that could significantly reshape  Congress & its attitude on crypto.

So don't get me wrong: we shall fight. We shall fight in Congress, we shall fight in the courts, we shall fight in the fields & in the streets...

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ I'm as disappointed as anyone, but strategically, it's crucial we understand when to fight & when to keep our powder dry.

We made a big impact in DC during the Senate vote. That was our shot & we made it count. The broader politics have taken over now:
https://t.co/rEAMakhJ4r

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ Importantly, nothing will happen right away.

The crypto provisions don't go into effect until 2024 (for FY2023 reporting). We can try to get them repealed or amended before then.

They also need rulemaking from Treasury to define their scope. We'll be active in that process.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ The infrastructure bill is heading for a vote in the House.

Yes, the crypto provisions are just as bad as they were months ago. Yes, the impact of Section 6050I has been underexplored.

No, you don't need to call your reps. The political reality is: it's out of our hands now.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @FreddieRaynolds As I said, agency authority is under fire. Look at the EPA suit. Chevron is living on borrowed time.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @FreddieRaynolds I might agree if not for what's happening in the judiciary.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @FreddieRaynolds Again, this is about reading between the lines & understanding the context. Gov't agencies *never* admit lack of jurisdiction. The fact they even discuss this as a challenge speaks volumes. "Potentially" in fn. 36 tells you all you need to know. They're on shaky ground & know it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @FreddieRaynolds That's just not how DC works. If they didn't need more authority from Congress, they wouldn't use such strong language to describe the constraints holding them back. As always with policy docs, this is an exercise in reading between the lines & understanding the context.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @FreddieRaynolds It's extremely rare for gov't to ever admit that it lacks jurisdiction to do anything. The language in the executive summary is sending a clear message of uncertainty on that point. Agency authority is a much bigger issue than crypto & is under fire from all sides. We'll see.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Long story short, it sounds like nothing big will (or can) happen any time soon.

That's a good thing in my view, since the report clearly gets a lot of stuff wrong. It will (& should) take time to sort through what makes sense & what doesn't.

We'll get there. For now, carry on.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
In the meantime, the report seems to acknowledge that federal agencies lack the authority necessary to implement its many & varied recommendations.

The report tells FSOC to "consider steps available to it" -- "in the absence of Congressional action, which is urgently needed...."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
We'll have plenty of time to pick apart the new stablecoin report.

For now, the highlight in my mind is the recommendation that "Congress act promptly to enact legislation...."

Prompt action from this Congress on *anything* is unlikely, let alone on something like stablecoins.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @3solarmasses It's a tax on profits that result from capital formation. It's therefore a disincentive to capital formation in the USA. It's exactly the same thing.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @3solarmasses Sigh. So much for having a real discussion. Good luck.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @stefan__ionescu https://t.co/Yf0nv9qp9U

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @TorstiNisula @Larocatain The best financial advice most people ever get is "invest in low-cost index funds & let your wealth compound over a long time period, don't make the mistake of thinking you're a trader." A policy of mandatory forced selling to pay tax on unrealized (maybe temporary) gains is üëé

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Perrenod The average person is advised to invest in a 401k or IRA so they can defer taxes as long as possible, or to invest in passive index funds that compound over long time periods without tax liability.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @TorstiNisula @Larocatain I suppose it depends who's subject to the tax, but there are a *lot* of unrealized gains in restricted securities with no secondary markets in this country.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @Larocatain This is the equivalent of "American families have to balance their budgets, why can't the federal government do it too?"

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @TorstiNisula @Larocatain "Let's destabilize the financial system to create buying opportunities for hedge funds" is maybe not good policy.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @Larocatain There's no credit for capital losses if last year's capital gains tax has already been paid. You're stuck waiting & hoping for the day when you have gains to offset. This is just a complete nightmare of an idea.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@gabriel_mathy @Larocatain Property taxes don't have automatic withholding anywhere I know of....

You can't "withhold" unrealized capital gains tax if the value being taxed is tied up in volatile assets. You're just a forced seller holding the sale proceeds.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @3solarmasses To be clear, you're saying we can increase tax liability for a particular behavior without discouraging that behavior? It seems beyond doubt that if you make capital formation significantly more expensive, less will take place. Is there empirical evidence to suggest otherwise?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@gabriel_mathy @3solarmasses Tax efficiency is also a big selling point (or not) for retail products. I think that's one reason ETFs have become predominant over mutual funds in recent years.

There are tradeoffs of course; a balance must be struck. My view is taxing unrealized gains is a very bad tradeoff.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @3solarmasses It goes without saying that tax policy impacts economic behavior, no? Decades of offshoring, transfer pricing, etc. are empirical evidence. Anecdotally, I can tell you from experience that prospective tax liability is a major factor in VC/PE investment decisions.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @ScipioApucanus That is usually how these things go....

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @3solarmasses Oh, sorry, I thought we might have a real discussion for a moment. Obviously you know an unrealized capital gains tax wouldn't be limited to crypto.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gabriel_mathy @3solarmasses I know you're being sarcastic, but speculation is in fact the driving force behind capital formation, isn't it?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@3solarmasses @gabriel_mathy Everyone in the country has to become a trader, figuring out how to hedge volatility or time the market between the FMV snapshot & tax day. A nation full of forced sellers.

Even if that somehow worked, it would severely restrict capital formation & damage markets of all kinds.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @james_roe It won't help anyone for executives to take salary instead of stock. More likely it would force them to build their businesses in other countries, thereby restricting the tax base, eliminating jobs, crashing equity markets, & generally wreaking havoc on the financial system.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @james_roe These are two entirely separate concepts with entirely different implications. Lenders can take on default risk stemming from illiquidity & volatility of collateral if they want; that's their choice. But taxation would force holders to sell assets blindly into the market. Insane.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: The idea of taxing unrealized capital gains is so perplexing, so completely ridiculous, that it's hard to imagine anyone who knows anything about finance could possibly mean it seriously.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @mcuban @GaryGensler The magic of DeFi comes from its borderless, permissionless, censorship-resistant nature. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @mcuban @GaryGensler "Why not" is because an exchange protocol with a regulated whitelist isn't decentralized. By definition, it's under the control of whoever manages the whitelist. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Frances_Coppola @Arturo_P_A @Paolo_Bernardi The Howey test does *not* go beyond investment contracts. You're right that there are other types of securities with other tests & principles.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Frances_Coppola @Paolo_Bernardi There are also many products that simply don't fit any of the listed types of securities, in which case those products are excluded, & don't require an exemption.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Paolo_Bernardi @Frances_Coppola Why is "lawyer" in quotes?

name: Jake Chervinsky

This is 100% necessary for decentralized exchange. We better figure it out.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
It's great to see everyone excited about engaging in crypto policy after this whole fiasco.

My only advice for now is to avoid the "I just learned about the crypto lobby & I'm here to fix it" approach.

We have great orgs already. We need to support them, not start from scratch.

I think it's fair to say that while agency expertise is often valuable, agencies also tend to push for more authority, not less. It's up to Congress to decide if the cost-benefit weighs in favor of that result, not to defer.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @HoffProf I don't think it's abnormal to question the blurring of lines between the branches, or the wisdom of senators deferring to agency officials who aren't accountable to the public on matters of constitutional import. This is how surveillance programs tend to get out of control.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

4/ Thankfully, some smart Senators understood that the language in the original draft was unworkable.

It treats everyone in crypto like a traditional financial institution no matter how different they are, & forces them to report data to the IRS that they don't have & can't get.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ This definition is wildly overbroad. It captures nearly everyone in crypto, forcing them all to surveil users in order to comply with tax reporting obligations.

We spent all week asking Congress to remove it, change it, or add exceptions for miners, developers, & many others.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Q: Could the infra bill apply to NFTs?

A: Yes.

The bill defines "digital asset" broadly, as "any digital representation of value‚Ä¶recorded on a cryptographically secured distributed ledger[.]"

If Treasury says this includes NFTs, then NFT issuers, merchants, etc. are brokers.

Stay tuned for updates.

[end]

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

I don't think the courts will take kindly to a law forcing non-custodial actors to surveil US citizens on behalf of the IRS.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

Lastly, everyone, top up your donations to @coincenter. They may need it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
18/ If you're a US citizen, call your Members of Congress, especially Sen. Portman if you're in Ohio.

If anyone says "this won't help" after we held off FinCEN & the FATF, I'll lose my mind.

Find your House Rep: https://t.co/5mT43dHldF
Find your Senator: https://t.co/zHugKZK7jj

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
17/ So, what can we do?

To start, don't panic. This provision isn't final yet & still can be changed.

Even if it passes as-is, it shouldn't take effect until 2023 at earliest, so at least we'll have time to try to undo it, in Congress or the courts. This may be a long fight.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
16/ Fifth, the burden it'll place on civil rights is unacceptable.

Our 4A right to privacy limits how much surveillance government can mandate without a warrant, & in a post-SolarWinds world, the last thing we need to do is expose more sensitive information to a security breach.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
15/ Fourth, it short-circuits the discussion we've been having with FinCEN.

Since President Biden took office, FinCEN has done a ton of solid work on crypto AML regulation. We should keep that process going, not cut it off by sneaking KYC in through the Tax Code's back door.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
14/ Third, it won't work. For every new dollar of tax revenue, we'll lose two (or ten) as the US crypto industry shuts down or goes offshore.

And instead of getting more insight into taxable crypto gains, the IRS will get less, as more users "go dark" on unregulated platforms.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
13/ Second, it'll be a huge foreign policy failure.

After China made the geopolitical blunder of forcing miners out of their country, many of us hoped the US would take market share in this crucial sector.

We can't make the same mistake China did. We have to stay in the game.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ This is a deeply misguided provision that, if adopted, will do far more harm than good to US interests.

I'll give you my top five reasons why.

First, it defies logic to adopt a regulation for which compliance is literally impossible, unless the goal is to kill the industry.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ The infrastructure bill is estimated to cost > $1 trillion. Congress scored the new "broker" definition at $28b in added tax revenue.

I have no clue how they got this number, or how it's even possible to calculate.

Regardless, this is no way to handle major new regulations.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ There are three main ways to raise revenue in a bill like this: increase current taxes, add new taxes, or improve tax compliance.

This allegedly falls in the third category‚Äîmaking people pay taxes they already owe. Congress thinks crypto is full of tax evaders. (It isn't.)

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ What does crypto have to do with infrastructure, you may ask?

The bill has to include "pay-for" provisions to raise revenue for new spending so that it's revenue-neutral as a whole. The "broker" definition is one of the pay-for provisions in the Senate draft of the bill.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ This sounds insane, but it really might happen.

Most crypto legislation goes nowhere, so it's easy to ignore. Not this time.

This provision is part of the bipartisan & otherwise popular infrastructure bill, which is moving quickly through Congress & is highly likely to pass.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ As those who understand crypto already know, users are pseudonymous & access is permissionless.

It's literally impossible for non-custodial actors like miners to get the information they need to do Form 1099s.

In practice, this could mean a de facto ban on mining in the USA.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ This means brokers have to KYC customers to comply with IRS reporting requirements.

As a result, the provision functions as a surveillance mandate, just like the one Sec. Mnuchin proposed in the final days of the Trump administration.

As before, this is a very bad idea.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ The Tax Code requires brokers to comply with IRS reporting requirements. Most importantly, they have to give Form 1099s to their customers & file them with the IRS too.

To fill out Form 1099s, brokers have to collect customer data including name, address, phone number, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ It might include a huge range of DeFi market participants too, like DEX LPs, liquidators, protocol governors, etc.

Depending what "for consideration" means, it might also extend to non-economic actors like node operators or wallet developers.

The scope here could be massive.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ This definition is so broad, it could apply to nearly every economic actor in the US crypto industry, if read literally.

That includes PoW miners & PoS validators, since "providing a service to effectuate transfers of digital assets for consideration" seems to fit both.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ The bill expands the definition of a "broker" to include "any person who (for consideration) is responsible for and regularly provides any service effectuating transfers of digital assets."

Earlier drafts said "even if non-custodial" & explicitly included DEX & P2P markets.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ üö® Here's the deal with the US infrastructure bill:

A new provision has been added that expands the Tax Code's definition of "broker" to capture nearly everyone in crypto, including non-custodial actors like miners, forcing them all to KYC users.

This is not a drill üëá

name: Jake Chervinsky

In that case, the money transmitter is reporting on their own financial activity with each of the peers, not merely spying on them from a distance & reporting theirs.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

If a dystopian surveillance state of this sort is constitutional, the Fourth Amendment will have lost all meaning.

Our first response is always to argue the merits: how the technology can reshape finance for the better, why the benefits far exceed the costs.

But our second has to be: "go ahead, give it a try."

I also don't think a nonprofit & a more crypto-native DAO are mutually exclusive; they're different projects in important ways & maybe we ought to try both simultaneously. @amico_jeffrey's post re: "PolicyDAO" has some good ideas to consider.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@DennisonBertram I'd be happy with that.

Deliverables are a bit complex b/c the work product can be hard to show (i.e., relationship-building w/ policymakers), but I think everyone gets that & can judge accordingly. Other deliverables are easier & can be prioritized (hiring, publications, etc.).

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@DennisonBertram It isn't clear how the rules of professional responsibility apply to a lawyer's relationship w/ a DAO, so most aren't willing to enter one. Same w/ other contractors, too.

I support funding at intervals. There's no reason this needs to be done in one shot, or by Uniswap alone.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@DennisonBertram We're unlikely to solve the challenge of a DAO engaging lawyers, etc. in a reasonable timeframe so as to still have a meaningful impact on policy. This probably just means working with less capable firms & less effectively.

As usual, a tradeoff b/w decentralization & efficiency.

tweet: @robustus I wouldn't expect them to go quite so far, but the BSA does give them authority to define new types of regulated FIs, & at least in theory they could try adding a new category that goes beyond custodial intermediaries. They shouldn't, & I hope they won't, but that's where we are.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@intjr @jpscasteras Congress has little appetite to do anything at all, let alone something as "soft on crime" as protecting financial privacy rights. The political will just isn't there.

SCOTUS, however, has shown interest in revitalizing 4A (see Riley, Carpenter) & I think would be open to this.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@StackinBits 4A didn't make a very successful transition into the digital era like some other civil rights have (1A has done much better).

It's not unusual in the history of constitutional jurisprudence for civil rights to rise & fall in strength. Right now, it's high time for a 4A revival.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Listen closely when gov't officials talk about "the importance of privacy."

Typically, they mean privacy from corporations or other individuals. Those are fine. Good, even.

They rarely mean privacy from *them.*

Thankfully, we have this little thing called the Fourth Amendment.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @jpscasteras If it's anything less than full KYC for all users & warrantless surveillance of all transactions, I'll be shocked. When they talk about privacy, they only mean privacy from each other / corporations, not from them.

The SEC won't approve an ETF without trade surveillance over "regulated markets of significant size." This crash implies unregulated markets are still the significant ones.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
"AML/KYC"

This term is so standard we almost forget that AML & KYC are distinct concepts. Anti-money laundering (AML) is the goal. Customer identification (KYC) is a strategy to achieve that goal‚Äîone that sacrifices privacy & relies on intermediaries.

We need a better strategy.

@SHodyEsq The term DAO itself is a little frustrating, too. Is it even possible for something to be an "organization" if it's meaningfully decentralized & automated? I tend to agree with this üëá which throws a wrench in the legal & policy analysis (as you identify):
https://t.co/LO1M5WmJFO

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @SHodyEsq I'd also say your formulation of "it‚Äôs a DAO so there‚Äôs no one to tax / regulate / sue" is just a shallow narrative & not really the prevailing perspective among those working deeply on DAOs. Nobody who understands the nuance thinks this is how policy will ultimately come out.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @SHodyEsq Sure, that's just not what I took from your OP. You asked if DAOs improve on the corporate structure or just seek to evade existing laws. My answer is that DAOs are indeed qualitatively different & the question of how existing laws should (or will) apply is separate & unresolved.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
In case you missed it, I've started writing a newsletter on legal, regulatory, & policy developments in crypto. I put out a Q1 2021 review a few weeks ago: https://t.co/1Xn6hBXTfm

Next week, I'll publish an April 2021 review. What happened this month that you want me to discuss?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@SHodyEsq 2/ Whether participants in DAOs should get different legal treatment is a much longer conversation, & if they actually *will* is yet another issue.

But from a policy perspective, many laws applying to traditional entities don't make sense or are superfluous in the DAO context.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@SHodyEsq 1/ It depends how you define a DAO, but it's more than "organizational governance tech." There's no real precedent for a system that continues operating even if all the human actors disappear. Limited liability isn't the goal & LLCs/corps aren't analogous:
https://t.co/peXppYLdQ3

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @SHodyEsq I'm very willing to make the case & strongly disagree that it's remotely about "evading existing laws." I'll try to make time to write more on this, but I think Vitalik did a pretty good job back in 2014 ("automation at the center, humans at the edges"): https://t.co/MaqW3EZAdN

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky

Uniswap Labs is a software developer & has a copyright in the v3 code as its creator. Its ability to enforce that copyright is distinct from whether it operates the code as an FI. Same as other regtech devs that license software to FIs.

- 60 more days if they need more time

for a total of 240.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @CatfishFishy @Uniswap I understand the critique. The difference is that the license explicitly grants governance the power to accelerate the conversion to GPL. It's hard-coded. Nobody ever promised that governance would be involved in v3 development & governance can stick with v2 if it wants.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
14/ It'll be fascinating to see how other projects react to this, if the copyright is ever enforced, if UNI governance speeds up GPL conversion, & if new DeFi projects use BSL 1.1.

No matter what, it's an elegant bit of legal innovation for DeFi. üëè @haydenzadams @ammori

[end]

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
13/ Given all this, I think it's premature to say BSL 1.1 should be the new standard for every DeFi project in every circumstance.

"Uniswap did it, so we should too" may seem tempting, but the reality is every project is different & very few are positioned as well as Uniswap.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ BSL 1.1 also may have regulatory impact. In general, the more privileges a DeFi developer keeps & exercises, the more centralization concerns there may be.

That's not to say BSL 1.1 is a problem on its own‚Äîit just needs to fit into a broader, well-calibrated legal strategy.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ That said, BSL 1.1's two-year delayed conversion to GPL seems to strike a fair balance between creating a copyright moat & open-sourcing the protocol.

Personally, I like it a lot, especially since UNI holders can accelerate the conversion at any time. Governance decides. ‚úÖ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ This may come at a cost, though.

As I said before, it's crucial for DeFi protocols to be free & open-source. BSL 1.1 software is not.

Many people in DeFi feel strongly about this, so there's reputation risk to an aggressive copyright enforcement strategy. It might backfire.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ So, if you're asking "how will Uniswap enforce against an anon dev team or a decentralized protocol," you have the wrong question.

The value of the BSL 1.1 license isn't just to stop forks from being launched, it's to stop forks from becoming widely adopted & successful.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ Third, even if enforcement is difficult or impractical, the threat alone will likely have a chilling effect on anyone thinking of going near a v3 fork.

This is basically "target hardening" for software. @collins_belton explains how effective it can be:
https://t.co/qKejSQ3TV0

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ This means Uniswap could (in theory) go after known third parties that adopt, integrate, support, or use an infringing v3 fork / its related assets.

We're talking exchanges, DEX aggregators, investors, LPs, MMs, you name it.

It just depends how aggressive they want to be.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ Second, dev teams aren't the only viable target.

US law also allows copyright holders to sue third parties for "contributory" copyright infringement even if they didn't commit any infringing acts directly.

Other theories of secondary liability may apply to third parties too.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ Understandably, Uniswap might not want to see another vampire attack on v3, or to have it turned into Waffleswap or whatever.

Copyright law is one possible solution. This is what it's for‚Äîit gives developers the right to decide who can copy, modify, & distribute their code.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ For reasons that I hope are obvious, it's crucial for DeFi protocols to be free & open-source software.

As a result, most DeFi protocols are launched with fully open-source licenses like MIT, BSD, & GPL. Uniswap v2 was released under GPL.

Then Sushi & Pancake happened....

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ NOT LEGAL ADVICE

(sorry, couldn't resist the reference)

But seriously, I'm not your lawyer. If you have a DeFi copyright issue, hire your own. Don't try to get legal advice from Twitter.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ One interesting piece of Uniswap v3 is its use of Business Source License (BSL) 1.1, which restricts production use for two years.

I see people asking if @Uniswap can really use BSL 1.1 against v3 forks. Answer: yes, mostly, at a cost.

The DeFi + copyright situation üëá https://t.co/KYQZTl58Ht

@brianlfrye @BenPEdwards For example, Howey asks what managerial & entrepreneurial efforts an issuer carries out to yield profit for the enterprise.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@brianlfrye @BenPEdwards But what information asymmetry exists between artist & art purchaser that the securities laws could possibly solve? This makes no sense.

In that light, when you consider & apply the Howey factors to the sale of art, it takes an extreme contortion to make any of them fit.... 2/

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @brianlfrye @BenPEdwards In part, I agree with the "shadow factor" concept, which I think is directly captured in case law by the focus on "economic reality," recognizing that the securities laws apply where disclosures are needed to address information asymmetries between issuers & investors.... 1/

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @__amirs__ @cyrxopto Seller & buyer are the same person in your hypothetical. Crypto does not help with this.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @__amirs__ @cyrxopto You don't have to believe me if you don't want to, but I spend a lot of time working on this issue & I'm telling you otherwise.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @__amirs__ @cyrxopto What you're missing is that the guy selling the NFT will receive BTC easily traceable back to a suspicious transaction (conversion from XMR), which will more likely result in enhanced due diligence & discovery of his criminal conduct than if he hadn't done the NFT sale at all.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @cyrxopto @__amirs__ üíØüëÜ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @__amirs__ @cyrxopto Like I said, you clearly don't know how AML works in crypto.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @__amirs__ @cyrxopto Converting XMR to BTC without the conversion itself being surveilled is practically impossible. Buying an NFT with that BTC & then trying to cash out the BTC will earn you a ton of questions. This is a great way to make yourself a law enforcement target. Otherwise, stupid.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @__amirs__ @cyrxopto It's pretty clear you don't know how AML works in crypto. Other than XMR, darknet transactions are tracked carefully. There aren't significant XMR/NFT sales, as far as I'm aware. If there were, you'd better believe they'd get enhanced due diligence. This would be extremely dumb.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @__amirs__ @cyrxopto In this scheme, there's literally no reason to put any of the transactions you've mentioned on a blockchain. The drug dealer doesn't need NFTs to pretend he's an artist. Using crypto makes this scheme easier to detect & unwind, not harder.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @__amirs__ @cyrxopto That's not how it works. The drug dealer first has to place the $1m into the crypto ecosystem. If he succeeds, his sale "to himself" will be forever recorded on a public ledger. He then gets a traceable, illiquid work of digital art. Worst money laundering scheme in history.

tweet: @attorneyjeremy @GooGooGorilla There isn't a formal "estoppel" defense in the enforcement context, but it's a good way to think about fair notice; it typically requires an affirmative assurance of non-enforcement, which I don't think Ripple alleges they ever received. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @attorneyjeremy @GooGooGorilla Yes. It depends how the court interprets the scienter requirement for aiding & abetting, i.e., whether the SEC must prove only knowledge of facts constituting a violation or knowledge of impropriety (there's case law in both directions) but it could be relevant (not dispositive).

tweet: The entire world becomes much easier to understand when you realize that the economic value of any good or service is simply whatever someone will pay for it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@_BenWang @CaitlinLong_ @mises Credit has a precise definition in finance & law. It doesn't mean "any time anyone trusts anything," which seems to be how you're using it.

There are certainly other risks in DeFi & although trust is minimized, it isn't eliminated, but that's not the same as "credit." 3/3

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@_BenWang @CaitlinLong_ @mises I suppose you could say DeFi suppliers "trust" those liquidation mechanisms to work, but that's like saying bitcoin holders trust miners to keep mining the blockchain.

True, in a sense, & this is why nothing is truly trustless (only trust-minimized) but that isn't "credit"... 2/

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @JamisonSites @CaitlinLong_ @mises It would make no sense to use the term "DeFi" to describe traditional loan agreements where the parties are identified & required to trust each other & the judicial system merely because those agreements are stored on a blockchain.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@HDPbilly @CaitlinLong_ @mises But that's the problem‚Äîby definition, a credit-based loan requires the lender to *trust* that the borrower will make repayment at a future date. The phrase "trustless lending" is basically an oxymoron.

Credit reports aren't trustless & producing them within DeFi is a nightmare.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@HDPbilly @CaitlinLong_ @mises I don't know that at all & there are many reasons to doubt it's even possible in the first place: DeFi seeks to minimize trust & credit is literally the definition of trust.

Are you aware of a project that will bring credit to DeFi in a commercially reasonable format?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@CaitlinLong_ @mises Credit is the great missing link in DeFi‚Äîthe ability to make unsecured loans so that borrowers can finance new projects using lenders' capital that they couldn't afford otherwise.

This is an unsolved problem, & given the unavoidable need for trust in lending, perhaps impossible.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@CaitlinLong_ @mises Although not in Misesian terms & not directly on-point, I wrote about the lack of credit (& the misuse of the terms "loan" & "lending") here:
https://t.co/lF2AggQK69

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@CaitlinLong_ @mises It's neither, really; there's no credit in DeFi of either sort since all borrowing is overcollateralized & no creditor-debtor relationships exist in a meaningful sense.

Yield comes from users willing to pay fees for financial services, some for trading purposes (vol) & some not.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@collins_belton @sbmeunier @RebeccaRettig1 @AaveAave @awrigh01 @lex_node "Same business, same risks, same rules."

From a regulatory perspective, DeFi gets really interesting when the technology fundamentally alters the business & risks, solving problems with code that could only be solved in traditional finance by imposing rules on intermediaries.

tweet: @icecreamman2011 @sladecrypto That's not really how it works. The tolling agreement gives the target of the investigation more time to try to convince the agency not to sue.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ork716 @Hopium4 @sladecrypto It's public policy *not* to make investigations public before they're finished, & for good reason. Investigations often don't reveal any wrongdoing, so it's critically important not to make allegations until they're supported. I wrote about this years ago:
https://t.co/aSb6eWHVR4

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@sladecrypto It wouldn't be appropriate for me to comment on XRP specifically, but in general, the statute of limitations is five years since the most recent violation (not the first one).

The SEC can also invoke the "continuing violation doctrine" to charge violations older than five years.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@CreativeHeroes @sladecrypto @HesterPeirce The term "security" is defined in federal law, 15 U.S.C. ¬ß 77b(a)(1): https://t.co/NNewf32hnM.

The type of security most often implicated by digital assets is the "investment contract," which is defined by case law & discussed in this 2019 SEC guidance: https://t.co/p0OCkgyHXc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @RailroadedMI I mean, yeah, it's legit. Some digital assets are securities. The term for them is "digital asset securities." what would you prefer?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@Valuemancer I sense sarcasm, but like...that's literally all it is üòÇ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
I'm seeing confusion about the SEC's use of the term "digital asset securities" in today's statement & recent court filings.

This term has been used since at least November 2018 (https://t.co/qIj6FMEfah) & simply refers to digital assets that are securities. Nothing too special.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @sladecrypto @HesterPeirce Investigations take time. It would be inappropriate for a government agency to make accusations of misconduct before the investigation is complete. They have until the end of limitations period (under the applicable statute of limitations) to formally allege a violation.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@JonRiceCrypto @ErikVoorhees Most 2016-17 ICOs were utility token projects with half-baked whitepapers proposing doomed-to-fail business models. Many were frauds.

To the extent that current projects started as ICOs (not many), they either pivoted hard or involve people who would've gotten funded otherwise.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@JonRiceCrypto @ErikVoorhees I didn't say "in trad VC world." Projects can be funded without doing a public token sale or going to Silicon Valley.

I disagree that a large portion of 2016-17 ICOs were innovative or that current success ties directly to that bubble, but it'd take us forever to litigate that.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @b05crypto @ErikVoorhees That's a totally fair critique / argument why the laws should change. It's just that from a practical perspective, if you're a founder trying to build a successful project in a world where laws & regulators do exist (like it or not), you're more likely to succeed if you comply.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@JonRiceCrypto @ErikVoorhees How is it myopic to decry fraud & misconduct?

A lot of people lost a lot of money in the ICO bubble, & not just because they made an informed decision to risk money on an uncertain result. Many of them were victimized. It's important to balance that cost against the benefit.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ErikVoorhees ...meanwhile, we've learned a ton about how to protect investors & mitigate regulatory risk, & grown to a point where it's worth the extra effort for the sake of industry maturity.

As you know, I fully support open experimentation in finance, but we can do better than ICOs. 3/3

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ErikVoorhees ...to where an ICO that might've been a risk worth taking seven years ago, & borderline-to-bad four years ago, is a pretty terrible idea today.

Funding is not a problem in 2021, whereas the risks of retail getting fleeced & founders getting shut down is higher than ever... 2/

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@davidiach @ErikVoorhees That's not the impression I mean to give at all.

I think there's a great discussion to be had re: whether securities laws are appropriate or not. But my focus is on the practical; we may not want the US to be "world securities police" but that's not far from the reality.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ErikVoorhees On balance, I think the degree of fraud & misconduct didn't justify the value that came from it. I think the legitimate projects would've gotten funded anyway.

Second-order effects are harder to judge, I admit. Maybe fewer people would be interested in crypto now. Hard to say.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ErikVoorhees Your point hits like a regulatory version of "efficient breach," where the benefits of violating a legal obligation (typically a contract) outweigh the costs.

There are many ways to evaluate this in the context of 2017 (I think ICOs were bad), but in 2021, it's hard to justify.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ErikVoorhees There's a really interesting conversation to be had here, which I ultimately think it boils down to:

- in principle, should the securities laws exist?
- since they do exist, how can we address them?

In a practical sense, I'd say a new round of I_Os is net negative all around.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gp_squadr @Florian7788 @attorneyjeremy It's totally fair & reasonable to say it bugs you & that the SEC should've figured out its view on XRP sooner & taken action earlier, if it was ever going to take action at all. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Florian7788 @attorneyjeremy It's not though. This is literally what the statute of limitations is for. The SEC has until the limitations period expires to allege a violation. It makes *no sense whatsoever* to say they were required to allege a violation to an unnamed exchange at some other time before then.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@JamesLoveYT @jesse_hynes ...& (3) reliance on the statement by the defendant, meaning the statement must come before the alleged violation, not in the course of investigating after-the-fact.

There may be other related theories & I have no opinion on how any of it may apply to Ripple or anyone else. 3/3

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @JamesLoveYT @jesse_hynes But importantly, in every circumstance I've seen, the defense requires: (1) an affirmative statement by regulators, not just a failure of speedy enforcement (that's addressed instead by the statute of limitations); (2) a statement to the defendant, not privately to 3rd parties...

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @JamesLoveYT @jesse_hynes I want to avoid legal advice here, but in general, there is a theoretical defense of reliance on a regulator's official interpretation of law. Typically this only applies to formal guidance, but could also apply to approvals or assurances of non-enforcement (again, in theory). 1/

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @edotanferri @TigerMike15 @jesse_hynes @xrpmeplz The only cognizable legal theory that asks "did the SEC wait too long to bring an enforcement action" is the statute of limitations. That's the law saying how long the SEC has to bring suit. If they brought suit within the limitations period, the rest is just bellyaching.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gladstein @panekkkk @AFDudley0 @fubuloubu @laurashin @chamath @synthetix_io This isn't a way of evading regulation, it's a way of eliminating the underlying risk (counterparty fails to send the security within T+2) that the regulation was designed to address (cash deposits to cover that risk), obviating the need for the regulation in the first place.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @gladstein @panekkkk @AFDudley0 @fubuloubu @laurashin @chamath @synthetix_io DeFi does fix (part of) the GME problem on a technical level, e.g., by eliminating the intermediary that caused Robinhood to halt trading. One issue was Robinhood's clearinghouse deposits, required to address counterparty risk created by T+2 settlement. DeFi eliminates that risk.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
The goal of DeFi is to eliminate the need to rely on financial intermediaries.

In Robinhood's case, the intermediary most responsible for yesterday's trading halts is the "clearinghouse," which finalizes trades & requires cash deposits to manage risk.

DeFi literally fixes this.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Fatalmeh @hasufl @MonetSupply Agreed. The average DeFi governance system is quite different from a corporation in many ways (especially operationally) & would take a lot of re-organizing to look like one. It's just always important to be careful about delegating (read: centralizing) from the whole to the few.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Fatalmeh @hasufl @MonetSupply I'm certainly not jumping to that conclusion. There are many instances where delegation is good & appropriate & not at all comparable to a shareholder/executive relationship. It's all facts & circumstances in the end, as always. But as I said earlier, it's a slippery slope.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @hasufl @MonetSupply We also *can* reinvent governance & there are many reasons to try. The traditional corporate structure isn't working for most people in the digital era: giant companies service their shareholders at the expense of their customers. The flat hierarchies of protocols can be better.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @hasufl @MonetSupply We don't *have* to reinvent governance, but if all we do is put a blockchain voting system into a traditional corporate structure with all its information asymmetries & fiduciary relationships, we should expect all the traditional corporate laws to apply. That's not very "DeFi."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@hasufl @MonetSupply We have decades of corporate law designed to address all the risks of shareholders relying on management, not least of which the securities laws.

There's a point where innovation stops & reinventing the wheel starts, except square this time.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @SignCurve @TheJusticeDept üëÄ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @hasufl @MonetSupply The problem is the risk of simply reinventing a corporation with shareholders & management. It's a slippery slope.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @hasufl @MonetSupply I agree with the former, I'm suspicious of the latter. It sounds more like centralizing governance decisions, not reducing the need for them.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @malifrenchbull Parties in US litigation usually have to pay their own fees. Lawsuits are expensive, so defendants often settle instead of fight; even if they think they'll win, they might still owe their lawyers millions of dollars. Forcing losers to pay winners' fees stops this extortion.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Under US copyright law, a plaintiff can be forced to pay the defendant's legal fees if the suit was brought "frivolously or in bad faith."

What do you think‚Äîwould it be "frivolous" or "in bad faith" for Craig Wright to claim he owns a copyright in the bitcoin whitepaper? Hmmm ü§î

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

@alexmagnusBTC @zndtoshi @RyanSAdams Right. The whole point is to reduce trust as much as possible. Hard cap (or any hard issuance rate) is better for that than minimum viable issuance.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@alexmagnusBTC @zndtoshi @RyanSAdams Granted, the easiest way to win this game is not to play, & that's what Bitcoin does with the hard cap. The only real risk is that fee markets may not provide security.

That's just a concern troll at this point, but I don't mind Ethereum experimenting with the backup option.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@alexmagnusBTC @zndtoshi @RyanSAdams No, but the Fed has to pull many levers (interest rates, open market operations, etc.) to influence many goals (inflation, employment, etc.) based on many metrics (cpi, exchange rates, etc.).

It is theoretically easier to adjust one factor (issuance) for one goal (security).

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@elpasobitcoin @zndtoshi It's literally not a scam. You may think it's doomed to fail, but let's save "scam" for when it's actually deserved.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ Make recommendations.

Giving good advice means having an answer for "what should we do?" Don't be the frustrating person who elevates problems without offering solutions. Be ready to recommend a course of action, but respect the decision even if goes a different way.

[end]

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ Remember, you're a counselor.

Your main job as counsel is to give good advice. Most business decisions rest with your CEO or another executive. Don't try to substitute your judgment for theirs; educate them so they can make informed decisions about cost/benefit & risk/reward.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ Be more than a cost center.

Legal is often viewed as a necessary burden weighing down a company's profit centers. Don't be. Instead, look for ways to be a savings center: identify valuable IP, streamline processes, network in your industry, etc. Be a partner in the business.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ "Yes, and."

Very few situations call for you to say "no, we can't do that, period." Always look for a "yes, and." "Yes, and we can do it better." "yes, and we'll need some design changes / compliance measures / etc." That's how you gain trust for when you do have to say "no."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ Ask questions.

You can't give good advice if you don't fully understand the goals your company wants to achieve. When legal questions come up, don't be tempted to give quick, shallow answers. Instead, ask "what are we trying to do? how? why?" Then work together on the answer.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @MattCorva @DLxLawLLP Your employees are lucky to have your reasoned perspective & the record set straight. I suspect this is the first battle of many (for better or worse) & if we don't win it, we'll live to fight another day, together.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @MattCorva It's not definitive at all, but as I'm sure we agree, a rule that leaves MSBs guessing & waiting for even more guidance from regulators (who have the power to interpret & enforce the rule however they see fit, behind closed doors) is unacceptable & against the spirit of the APA.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @MattCorva @DLxLawLLP Okay, that's fair. I also agree rules are inevitable (& can be good). I just don't want those rules to include gov't-mandated surveillance of every transaction, as we see in other countries. Financial privacy is important in my view & I think we shouldn't give a single inch.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @MattCorva There are MSBs that transfer assets into DeFi liquidity pools on behalf of customers. The question is whether those transactions have any "counterparties" for which information must be collected. The rule doesn't say. You can imagine arguments in both directions. It's a problem.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @MattCorva @DLxLawLLP I think you're advocating that we not bring all our weapons to bear on a bad rule just because it could be a worse rule. As a gov't affairs matter, the professionals with expertise on influencing policy will tell you that's just bad strategy. Quiet objections are easily ignored.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@MattCorva > "As long as users can withdraw to themselves"

There's still some debate about what due diligence has to be done for counterparty information. This may not be true under the current rule.

There are also potential implications for DeFi worth considering:
https://t.co/Q8nWnp4ND2

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @laurashin Yes.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@MattCorva Like I said, very close to being much worse.

But as in any negotiation, you can't let the other side anchor the debate with an extreme demand & then feel good settling for "not as bad as it could've been." It's the oldest tactic in the book & not one we should stand for.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @MattCorva We have to draw the line somewhere. There were versions of the rule that we wouldn't have opposed like this. It was the midnight process & inclusion of counterparty surveillance, genuinely a categorical expansion of the AML regime unique to crypto, that warranted taking a stand.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @MattCorva I know you're coming at this in good faith & we're on the same team -- I'd just encourage listening openly when so many people (including lobbyists who know the players in government & privacy advocates who know the issues deeply) are saying it's serious.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @MattCorva I agree it could've been much worse, but I think the reason many of us treat it as dire is because (1) it was *very* close to being *much* worse & we know the intent to make it much worse is there + (2) this is a slippery slope leading to a steep cliff. It's worth taking a stand.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@5omni Is this a BSV thing? I've heard this attempt to distinguish privacy & anonymity from a few BSV people now. It's incorrect.

Privacy on public ledgers with KYC at the on-ramps depends on the availability of anonymizing software. There's absolutely *nothing* wrong with anonymity.

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @jeff_paik I don't know what idea of "rights" you're talking about, but the entire point is that they are inalienable -- meaning the holder of a right has no obligation whatsoever to justify it, & it can't be taken away or transferred (unlike a privilege).

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @jeff_paik For most people, that's false. Bitcoin users are KYC'd at fiat on-ramps & their transactions are tied to their identities from that point forward. The only way for them to achieve privacy is to use anonymizing software. There is & should be absolutely nothing wrong with that.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@hectorr159 @jespow @NukeManDan It could just be a partner with significantly lower risk tolerance, not a true existential threat. That's been an issue for crypto companies maintaining banking relationships for a long time.

But even then, the problem is still downstream of a regulatory compliance concern.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@jeff_paik Show me a digital currency system that protects privacy without also providing anonymity & then we can discuss the importance of drawing the distinction.

I'm also not sure why you think "rights require responsibility." It sounds like you're confusing rights with privileges.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @jesse_hynes You're confusing two separate concepts. Bittrex customers are already KYC'd because Bittrex is a BSA-regulated institution. If they purchase XMR on Bittrex, that's not private. But once they *have* XMR, they should be able to transact it privately, just like cash. That's the law.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@creativejace @jesse_hynes @Snowden And as @Snowden would tell you, that monitoring does not always respect our constitutional rights.

There are many legal & practical limits on financial surveillance, like paper cash. Should we roll over & give up if government decided to ban cash because criminals use it?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@jesse_hynes > "In all other areas of life you have to disclose your investments"

This is wrong. The 4A guarantees freedom from unreasonable search & seizure, including re: financial transactions & investments. The government does not have an absolute right to surveil our economic lives.

+90 days for the ETF to address grounds for disapproval

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @stmdc @propelforward @BitGo OFAC sanctions enforcement, like *all* law enforcement, depends on investigators having the data they need to make their case. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@jesse_hynes Completely fair, & no matter her views, it may just not be appropriate to comment while the case is pending.

She dropped hints on her views re: Kik & Telegram while they were in progress, but didn't dissent until after settlement, so I agree we shouldn't read too much into it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Even without Jay Clayton, the majority of Commissioners have still voted to approve every action the Enforcement Division's proposed. There's no reason to believe he was a swing vote on this.

Anyway, it'd be a real shock for the SEC to bring a case & then abandon it weeks later.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Even so, she's the only one who's shown interest in voting not to approve crypto enforcement actions. You can see the results of Commission votes on district court actions here (after they're resolved): https://t.co/ESRuy38iIE.

You'll struggle to find "no" votes other than hers.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
To clarify the point re: Comm'r Peirce, she's often vocal when she disagrees with her colleagues on enforcement (e.g., Kik, Unikrn).

That she hasn't commented may suggest she approved. OTOH, it may be inappropriate to speak up while charges are pending, so it might mean nothing.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@fredostat @HesterPeirce When she's gone against her colleagues, she's often written dissents or made remarks saying so. For example, Unikrn (https://t.co/q6PwgbLrUC).

But she certainly isn't required to dissent if she votes no, & it may not be appropriate to comment while charges are pending.

name: Jake Chervinsky

tweet:

To start, the @coincenter team is all over this, as always. Check out their great blog post & detailed comment letter in this thread:
https://t.co/BRFt0w9hGE

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ TIP 5: KEEP IT SIMPLE.

A few clear & sharp paragraphs is plenty. Use plain & straightforward language. You don't have to write a whole book or a fancy poem. Don't bother with logic puzzles, rhetorical questions, or hypotheticals.

Finally, don't forget Tip 1: be respectful!

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ TIP 4: BE SPECIFIC.

Give concrete, detailed examples of how the rule would affect you. Don't just complain generally about how you don't like it. You can also share your thoughts on the process surrounding the rule, such as if you'd like more than 15 days to write a comment.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ TIP 3: MAKE IT PERSONAL.

Start by saying who you are & how you know what you're talking about. Then focus on how the rule would affect you personally, or how it would affect your company or business. Stick to what you know. Leave the complex legal arguments to the lawyers.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ TIP 2: DO YOUR RESEARCH.

Make sure you fully understand the rule & its impact. Your comment will be easy to disregard if you get the facts wrong. I'll link more resources below to help with this, but you can start with my last thread & the rule itself:
https://t.co/J7euIbekqw

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ Here are five tips for writing a clear & effective comment.

TIP 1: BE RESPECTFUL.

This is really a requirement, not a tip. Be firm, but polite. Don't write anything you wouldn't say to your mother. Don't use insults or profanity. Focus on the rule, not the people behind it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ First, let me assure you that public comments do matter. 

A LOT.

Agencies have to read & respond to the substance of every single one. Your voice will be heard. It might change minds on the other side. Even if not, it still might slow them down.

This is worth your time.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@EpsilonTheory @AriDavidPaul @EthVangelist 1/ This year's FATF 12-month review considered peer-to-peer transactions & found "insufficient evidence" to warrant changes to AML regulation (pp. 14-15 https://t.co/txQgawGBjL).

The rule FinCEN proposed (known as the Swiss Rule) is the furthest any major jurisdiction has gone.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@EpsilonTheory @AriDavidPaul @EthVangelist For many reasons, I disagree as a legal matter (those laws are specific to physical transport, crypto doesn't exist in any one place, etc.).

But more importantly, as a practical matter, there are no signs that policymakers are considering this. It's not a very realistic concern.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@AriDavidPaul @EthVangelist @EpsilonTheory Also, the rule *couldn't* apply to transfers between individuals, even if the Treasury Secretary wanted it to.

Treasury's rulemaking powers are limited to the authority delegated by Congress via statute. Federal law only authorizes rulemaking applying to financial institutions.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@zenzeizen @EpsilonTheory If you want to get technical, it applies to "financial institutions" defined by statute in 31 U.S.C. ¬ß 5312(a)(2) & by regulation in 31 C.F.R. ¬ß 1010.100(t).

Individuals acting on their own behalf are not financial institutions. The BSA does not & cannot extend that far.

name: Jake Chervinsky

We've become extremely anti-fragile.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
19/ For everyone else, the best thing you can do to help in the fight for financial privacy & self-custody is to *do it yourself.*

Walk the walk. Learn to protect your own privacy & safely hold your own keys. Run a node. Use products & services that respect these principles too.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
18/ For my part, I'll be helping @BlockchainAssn evaluate grounds to challenge the rule under the APA. They've hired one of the best lawyers in the country for this.

If you're a crypto company in the US & haven't talked to them about joining, do it now.
https://t.co/sf73V6bTM1

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
17/ So, we have an awful rule crafted in a bad process. What now?

To start, we should take advantage of our limited public comment period & make our voices heard loud & clear.

I expect there will be a template comment form with suggested language to make this easy. Stay tuned.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
16/ Midnight rulemaking implies that an agency isn't giving the public a genuine opportunity to participate in the rulemaking process, but rather trying to force through a predetermined result.

Courts don't take kindly to this. Midnight rules are often struck down under the APA.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
15/ Regular order calls for an agency to accept public comment for at least 60 days for "significant" rules. It can be longer.

FinCEN is giving us 15. At the end of December. With one month left before a new president is sworn in.

There's a name for this: "midnight rulemaking."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
14/ The Administrative Procedures Act (APA) requires agencies to provide notice of proposed rules & give the public "an opportunity to participate in the rulemaking through submission of written data, views, or arguments."

The law says these mandates are "not mere formalities."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ Put this together & you have the definition of bad regulation.

The rule would impose huge burdens on VASPs, their customers, & society at large, perhaps infringing constitutional rights, without conveying any benefit to government in general or law enforcement in particular.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ Without a clear path to compliance, it'll be left to the discretion of regulators & prosecutors to decide if a VASP's efforts are "good enough."

We've seen this before: institutions don't know how to comply, so they "de-risk" by prohibiting the uncertain activity completely.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ Third, the rule is vague & ambiguous.

How exactly can a VASP obtain the name & physical address of the owner of a non-custodial wallet? How does someone prove that they "own" a private key? What about non-custodial smart contracts -- who owns them?

The rule doesn't say.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ Considering the FinCEN Files leak & recent hacks, government hasn't really shown that it's using our information effectively or storing it safely.

Now isn't the time to expand government's warrantless mass surveillance & data collection operations.
https://t.co/pBVKoFlPzz

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ Second, it infringes on US citizens' financial privacy rights.

Today, law enforcement has to subpoena VASPs to get information about customers. VASPs can, should, & often do challenge these.

This rule would force VASPs to hand over that information automatically, every time.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ It doesn't stop VASP customers from transacting with bad guys. It just forces them to pay an extra fee to withdraw to their own wallet first.

It also doesn't give investigators any new information. VASPs already KYC their customers & keep records of transactions.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ But it's still an awful rule. I'll give you three reasons why. (There are more.)

First, it does nothing to accomplish its stated goals. Even if illicit activity was a major problem (it isn't), this won't stop the flow of funds to bad actors or help law enforcement do its job.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ Let's look on the bright side for a minute.

This doesn't require KYC for every transaction with a non-custodial wallet. It isn't an outright ban on self-custody. It doesn't prohibit the act of using a permissionless network.

It really -- REALLY -- could have been much worse.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ Before now, the Travel Rule only imposed these record-keeping & reporting requirements on transactions from VASP-to-VASP.

Today's proposal follows a global trend of extending AML regulation to transactions from VASP-to-wallet, as we've seen from Switzerland, France, & others.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ VASPs would also have to report any deposit or withdrawal > $10k to FinCEN in the form of a currency transaction report (CTR).

FinCEN says these requirements are necessary to "combat the financing of global terrorism," "address transnational money laundering...." You get it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ The rule would impose new obligations on virtual asset service providers (VASPs) like exchanges & custodians.

For deposits & withdrawals > $3k involving a non-custodial wallet, VASPs would have to record the name & physical address of the wallet owner.
https://t.co/H4UR4t11GX

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

It could've been worse (really), but it's still a terrible rule in both process & substance.

Here's what it says, what's wrong with it, & what we do next üëá

The Administrative Procedures Act (APA) requires federal agencies to accept & consider input from the public before adopting a new rule.

This not a mere formality.

By allowing only 15 days for public comment on a crucially important rule, FinCEN may be in violation of the APA.
