name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
From a legal perspective, it doesn't really matter what label you use to describe the act of holding your own private keys (unhosted, self-hosted, non-custodial, etc.).

It only matters that you *can* without unduly burdensome rules infringing on your property & privacy rights.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@zackvoell @notgrubles "Wallet" might be described as an "obtuse" way to describe a public/private key pair as well, but we still use it when it helps.

Experienced bitcoin users aren't the target audience here. This is about how to effectively message policymakers. It's okay if you don't like it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @zackvoell You have it backwards. Regulators seeking to normalize third-party custody use the terms "hosted" & "unhosted" to imply that self-custody is dangerous. "Self-hosted" was an honest (if imperfect) attempt to push back & put the focus on people exercising their self-sovereignty.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@zackvoell Completely agree but just fyi:
https://t.co/gRcq3bVD4e

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@notgrubles "Self-hosted" came about as a response to regulators using the terms "hosted" (safe & controlled) & "unhosted" (scary & wild!). It's meant to put focus on the people behind those wallets exercising their property rights & self-sovereignty.

Not saying I love it, just explaining.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@TusharJain_ That's the "decentralized" part, yes.

The "autonomous" part is that the owners (I wouldn't say shareholders) own something that self-executes without human intervention, as if a factory produced goods indefinitely on its own. It may be subject to, but does not depend on, people.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @mhonkasalo @TusharJain_ If a DAO "organizes itself out of flat hierarchy" enough that it's "very similar to a publicly-traded company," then it's not a DAO, it's a traditional (if unincorporated) organization that happens to use a blockchain for shareholders to cast votes.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@TusharJain_ Same situation with hiring engineers.

In a corporation, the shareholders don't vote on details like this; they choose management to do it for them (subject to fiduciary duties). that's why they're entitled to disclosures from management (to check their work). Not so in a DAO.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @TusharJain_ There are always power centers within flat hierarchies, but structural flatness (e.g., one person/token, one vote) is what matters. CEOs have rights & responsibilities (e.g., hiring/firing, fiduciary duties) that Andre doesn't (or shouldn't). So no, he isn't a CEO "in practice."

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @TusharJain_ If they're "very similar to publicly traded companies" then they're not really "DAOs" in any meaningful sense.

tweet: @GKeeto @coinbase The rumors are real, but any meaningful action would require a notice of proposed rulemaking & a public comment period. If that happens in the next month or two, every US citizen & company will have a chance to weigh in, & nothing can happen before Biden's folks take over.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @regulatorynerd So while I agree we need to figure out how law enforcement can do its job & prevent bad actors from abusing this new blockchain-based financial system, I don't think forcing exchanges to collect hardware wallet sales receipts or solicit screenshots of Metamask is the ticket. 5/5

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@regulatorynerd Even if you're right about facilitation, the sanctions laws don't impose affirmative regulatory obligations & OFAC's compliance framework calls for a risk-based approach.

But prohibiting (a) doesn't mitigate risk! It's the definition of bad regulation: all cost, no benefit. 4/

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@regulatorynerd And prohibiting both (a) & (b) is just like saying "it's illegal for exchanges to allow customers to take possession of their own assets or interact with public blockchains."

Setting aside issues of constitutionality, a rule like that is guaranteed to backfire in the extreme. 3/

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@regulatorynerd Anyway, this is about a regulation that would distinguish:

(a) customer withdraws from exchange to SDN address, vs.
(b) customer withdraws from exchange to personal address & sends to SDN address.

As a policy matter, prohibiting only (a) & not (b) has zero meaningful impact. 2/

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@regulatorynerd To hold exchanges liable for processing transactions with "unverified" wallets, we'd have to accept an all-consuming construction of "facilitation" under the sanctions laws.

For a lot of reasons, we shouldn't, & in both guidance & enforcement practice, neither do OFAC or DOJ. 1/

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@peter @regulatorynerd There's nothing stopping crypto exchanges from filing SARs on whatever withdrawals (or deposits) they please. They can already do this with the help of blockchain analytics.

A new requirement for "KYPK" (know your private key?) wouldn't be treating paper & digital cash equally.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @vtKMH @balajis @coinbase Something like this would require a notice of proposed rulemaking & a public comment period (which is what Sec. Mnuchin is rumored to be pushing forward). Then every US company & citizen will have the opportunity to make their voices heard. This isn't a done deal. we can stop it.

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @regulatorynerd This is a bad take. When we take cash from an ATM & put it our pocket, we don't have to prove to the bank that our pants belong to us, & they're not liable for how we use that cash afterward. Digital cash shouldn't be treated any differently. Brian's 100% right to push back here.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Macro_Guy @matt_odell In other words, it's not an IOU for BTC, it's an IOU for the money you give them plus or minus any change in BTC's price.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Macro_Guy @matt_odell They will hold BTC in your name, but never let you take custody of it -- so what you're buying is exposure to BTC's price movement (essentially a derivative), not BTC.

name: Jake Chervinsky

@XxencryptxX @zackvoell It's a civil forfeiture action. These are called "in rem" actions, meaning "against the property." They're required for the government to take lawful possession of the property.

Anyone who has a valid claim to the property can come forward & contest the government's allegations.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @HamEggsnSam If you operate in the US market, you're subject to US law & the jurisdiction of US regulators. It doesn't matter where you have your headquarters. There's no "regulatory clarity" to be gained simply by moving an office overseas. Look at what happened to BitMEX, for example.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@HamEggsnSam Okay, & in the meantime, we'd expect Ripple to withdraw completely from the US market?

This is the point I was trying to make: it's pretty remarkable for a US company that raised millions of dollars from US investors to give up on the US market. It's a huge blow to the business.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@HamEggsnSam Has anyone at Ripple given a reason other than securities classification for wanting to move offshore?

Most FIs don't fear enforcement. They work with regulators to make sure their products & services are compliant. Giving up on that effort is extremely rare & a huge deal.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @nic__carter @NYcryptolawyer @Filecoin @protocollabs @HesterPeirce Right. & it doesn't even really make sense to withhold basic information like that. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@MonetSupply @DLTspecialist @TheBlock__ The pawnbroker also typically won't care what the item is worth & whether its market value fluctuates as long as the borrower makes contractually-obligated payments, e.g. 5% interest per month in perpetuity.

This depends on the borrower's creditworthiness, not the asset's value.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @MonetSupply @DLTspecialist @TheBlock__ ...in the meantime, the pawnbroker is deprived of the asset it actually wants (cash). If the borrower fails to repay, then the pawnbroker has to sell the item to someone else in order to get that cash, with no guarantee that they'll make enough to cover the loan in a future sale.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@MonetSupply @DLTspecialist @TheBlock__ "Within a certain time period" is a major difference.

There's an ongoing relationship between the parties; the pawnbroker is obligated to keep the item (in custody) & the borrower has a limited right to repurchase it from the pawnbroker (not just openly on the market). And...

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@DLTspecialist @MonetSupply @TheBlock__ I explain in the article why this isn't just semantics.

99.99% of people who hear "lending" think of transactions in which one person gets to spend someone else's money on the promise of repayment later & with risk of default. That's fundamentally not what DeFi does (or can do).

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@NYcryptolawyer @Filecoin @protocollabs I mean, everything about them is different.

Statements about expected future efforts, network maturity at launch, secondary market activity, token design & value accrual mechanisms, promises about all of these things . . .

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@MonetSupply @TheBlock__ That's not quite right.

It's true that overcollateralization & credit can co-exist; for example, a mortgage is a loan overcollateralized by real property, but the relationship is still one of creditor & debtor with attendant rights & obligations. DeFi transactions are different.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
20/ I fear we're heading for a world where withdrawing crypto from exchanges to self-custody is restricted as a means of attacking privacy.

We'd have two separate crypto markets: one of "clean" custodial coins & another of "dirty" self-sovereign ones, with no bridge between.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
19/ I won't bother reciting all the recent gov't statements targeting financial privacy as a major risk. There are too many.

The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) said it all in its report on central bank digital currencies last week:

"Full anonymity is not plausible." https://t.co/e9uxPBEWLV

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
17/ Perhaps most importantly, policymakers *worldwide* are signaling a desire to expand existing laws to restrict access to crypto.

Consider the "Swiss Rule," which practically prohibits self-custody in the guise of verifying the owner of a private key.
https://t.co/YQ4RGOpgp8

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
16/ The phrase "...whether it is possible..." is heavily loaded.

Translated into DC speak, this means "we definitely don't think it's possible, so you better not, or else."

Keep in mind, this is a DOJ that disapproved of end-to-end encryption yesterday:
https://t.co/11wun64Phg

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
15/ They're also attacking privacy more aggressively.

Last week's DOJ Framework described anonymous transactions as "a high-risk activity...indicative of possible criminal conduct."

And it had an ominous warning for exchanges about "anonymity enhanced cryptocurrencies" (AEC): https://t.co/IjbOsUMBbz

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
14/ So, what are they doing?

For starters, they're enforcing current AML regulations more aggressively.

Most of us expected BitMEX to get tagged by the CFTC for unregistered derivatives trading, but it was a big deal to see DOJ turn the case criminal. That doesn't happen often.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
13/ However, over the last year, Bitcoin has gained geopolitical significance & fiat-pegged stablecoin volume has exploded upward.

As a result, gov'ts are getting more concerned about both illicit activity & the threat to their monetary sovereignty (a topic for another day).

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ Second, gov'ts can track crypto transfers via blockchain analytics fairly easily, even supposedly private ones (sorry to break it to you).

Third, there really isn't that much criminal activity in crypto, so the overall risk is low & hasn't warranted a ton of gov't resources.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ There are a few reasons for this.

First, gov'ts have been content to regulate on-ramps & off-ramps, partly on the belief that crypto's main utility comes from conversion into fiat.

They've been satisfied by limiting access to conversion & catching criminals in the process.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ For years, regulators have cracked down on digital transfers that use institutions like money transmitters & offshore banks.

But aside from the occasional "[country X] bans Bitcoin" headline, most gov'ts haven't tried to significantly restrict Bitcoin or other blockchains.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ Many gov'ts would love to get rid of paper cash & some are trying.

But paper cash doesn't pose that big a risk. Like gold, it only works for in-person transfers & isn't easy to move long distances in large amounts.

Regulators are much more concerned about digital transfers.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ AML regulations break down in the context of cash.

With no intermediary to deputize, gov'ts are less able to detect transactions, identify counterparties, determine sources of funds, conduct censorship & seizure, etc.

This is true for both paper cash & electronic cash.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ AML regulations depend on intermediaries to perform the functions of identification, surveillance, censorship, seizure, exclusion, & more.

Enter Bitcoin -- a peer-to-peer electronic cash system that lets anyone transfer any amount of value to anywhere without intermediaries.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ AML regulations seek to accomplish this goal by deputizing financial institutions, the gatekeepers of the financial system, to act like government agents.

For example, regulated institutions are required to identify customers, surveil transactions, & file reports with gov't.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ AML regulations are intended to prevent criminals from using & abusing the financial system.

The goal is to make sure that "crime doesn't pay" -- to stop bad actors from spending illegally-obtained funds & to help law enforcement detect & prosecute the underlying crimes.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ There's some regulation at the on-ramps & off-ramps, but so far, not enough to seriously infringe on the freedoms of self-custody & privacy.

This is changing.

Policymakers' approach to AML regulation is shifting significantly toward harsher restrictions on a *global* scale.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ Crypto market infrastructure has improved dramatically in recent years.

It's now quite easy for most people to convert fiat into crypto, withdraw any amount to their own wallet, & then do as they wish without restriction or identification, subject only to the consensus rules.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ This thread is long but very important.

If you believe in the principles of financial privacy & self-sovereignty at the heart of Bitcoin, as I do, you need to pay attention now.

We've made the world stage, but our biggest challenges still lie ahead.
https://t.co/1yq6ewt5Yz

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
You buy a loaf of bread from a bakery.

The bakery buys flour wholesale.

The wholesaler pays a trucking company for delivery.

The trucker buys gas in cash.

The cash was once used in a drug deal.

YOUR BREAD IS TAINTED, YOU GO TO PRISON!

Is this how people think AML laws work?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
12/ It also depends on the nightmare of litigation & dispute resolution that would result from a bail-in.

It's impossible to predict whether the issuers might still have valid claims against the banks, or the holders against the issuers, or both against third parties, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
11/ All this depends on commercial & political considerations too.

Maybe banks or policymakers find ways to protect issuers if failing to do so has business or systemic risks.

But then issuers might be "too big to fail," opening them up to extraordinary new regulatory burdens.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
10/ To be fair, it would be good legal practice for the issuers to limit liability this way even if they do have protection against bail-ins.

But they're clearly not making any promises of protection like that, & they're armed & ready to leave holders with the bag if it happens.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
9/ Perhaps most on-point is PAX's force majeure clause.

It explicitly says PAX will not "be liable for our failure to perform any obligations under this Agreement due to events beyond our control" including "bank failures[.]"

So, there's that.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ Both also have provisions to protect them against claims by holders (& others) in case of loss:

- disclaimers of express & implied warranties
- limitation of liability clauses
- force majeure clauses

Plus the usual boilerplate on indemnification, release, arbitration, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ For example, both disclose:

- lack of deposit insurance
- risk of legislative or regulatory changes affecting value

And PAX explicitly says:

- "Any bond or trust account we may hold for the benefit of members may not be sufficient to cover all losses incurred by members."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ The issuers' user agreements seem to recognize this fact by transferring the risk of a bank failure & bail-in to the stablecoin holders.

Both outline risk factors & disclosures acknowledging (in varying degrees of detail & precision) the chance of loss due to bank failures.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ There's no way to be sure without seeing the contracts between the issuers & their banks, but these don't sound like special relationships conveying unusual privileges or protections.

If that's true, then issuers could be treated like any other depositor in case of a bail-in.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ The issuers' user agreements say dollars are:

- "held by Circle with its U.S. banking partners in segregated accounts, on behalf of, and for the benefit of, Users" (USDC)

- "deposited either in US insured depository banks or used to purchase US treasury bonds" (PAX)

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: 3/ The best place I can think of to look for insight on these questions is in the terms, conditions, & disclosures of the issuers' whitepapers, user agreements, & attestations (links at end of thread).

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ First, you have the stablecoin issuer & the bank custodying its reserve; is there anything special here to protect against a bail-in?

Second, you have the stablecoin issuer & the stablecoin holders; is there anything special here to give holders recourse in case of a bail-in?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ Great question.

The short answer (not legal advice) is the money probably gets bailed-in just like other deposits at the failed bank & no special dynamics protect stablecoin holders, afaik.

The longer answer requires looking at the relationships between all the parties . . .

This is wrong. The SEC has absolute regulatory authority over national securities exchanges under the (aptly-named) Exchange Act of 1934, which is a centerpiece of the U.S. federal securities laws. Listing exchanges must sponsor ETF proposals.

name: Jake Chervinsky

I think of credit delegation as a debtor assigning a line of credit to a third party under a new agreement. If you don't have a "line of credit" to start with, you can't assign one.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@AlecSha83693441 @RyanSAdams @BanklessHQ I addressed this in the article.

DeFi transactions are not the same as collateralized loans, which *don't* eliminate counterparty risk; they explicitly place identified counterparties in a relationship of creditor & debtor. The presence of collateral does not change that.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@bigterminal @BanklessHQ Read the article!

Credit risk: "will the debtor repay the loan?"

Market risk: "will asset prices move so quickly that the mechanics of overcollateralization & free market liquidation fail to cover collateral value?"

Totally different risks with totally different implications.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@JordanLzG @RyanSAdams @BanklessHQ @compoundfinance @AaveAave Check it out when you have a chance! üòâ

The essence is not the same; unlike debtors (Lombard or otherwise), DeFi borrowers don't make any promise of repayment. They can borrow & then walk away completely & suppliers don't know the difference (& don't need to, unlike creditors).

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@lex_node Our friend @collins_belton prefers "yield protocol" since "interest" still suggests lending; I'm indifferent.

I like your "network equity" concept too, but some lawyers hear "equity" & start looking for a 10-K.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
There's no such thing as a "DeFi loan." Few understand this.

The terms "lending" & "credit" get thrown around a lot, but they fundamentally misrepresent the financial activity that DeFi enables.

Thanks to @BanklessHQ & crew for the chance to explain why:
https://t.co/iaLgfPj6NP

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@bigterminal @BanklessHQ There are other risks--smart contract risk, market risk--but not *credit* risk (or "default" risk), which characterizes lending.

It's important to distinguish different types of risk, as they require different methods of analysis & are addressed by different forms of mitigation.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ But it's a far cry from the zero-to-one innovation that blockchains offer elsewhere, e.g., decentralized money.

It may be a case where a blockchain is better than an Excel spreadsheet or SQL database, but by how much . . . ?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ To be fair, you can solve these problems by designing new semi-composable protocols that allow some types of interesting transactions.

But these would have to be highly restricted; subject to (most of) the same intermediation & oversight as the old system. Again, that's fine!

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ Composability also means irrevocable transactions.

If a holder trades security token X for asset Y on a DEX, the issuer can't unwind the trade, even though the ability to do so is often necessary.

Composability is permissionless, but security tokens must be permissioned.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ Composability is also tough for security tokens, at least for now. This is largely due to regulation (in the US context) but not entirely.

For example, true composability means possession by pseudonymous parties, which is incompatible with owning shares of a corporation.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ Self-custody is extremely powerful for bearer assets like bitcoin, where the holder of a private key has an absolute, uncensorable property right to the value of the asset.

Security tokens aren't that; they derive value only if the issuer (a trusted third party) says they do.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ What *is* interesting, maybe revolutionary, is allowing self-custody of financial instruments & exposing them to the composability of open protocols.

The problem is that security tokens are somewhat unfit for these goals, not only due to regulation, but by their very nature.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ To me, this fits the blockchain use case of "companies can save a few dollars by automating their back office."

That's fine! Nothing wrong with that!

It's just not particulary interesting in the broader context of crypto, & it gives off a very "blockchain, not bitcoin" vibe.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @EthereumMaxima2 @TheCryptoLark @CFTC @TheJusticeDept You're badly misinformed. Market manipulation is not only illegal under the securities laws. It's also illegal in crypto markets under the commodities laws codified at 18 USC ¬ß 1348, 7 USC ¬ß 9, 7 USC ¬ß 13, & 17 CFR ¬ß 180.2 (at minimum). This is not a gray area or up for debate.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @nivertech @CFTC @TheJusticeDept The definition of a "commodity" under 7 U.S.C. ¬ß 1(a) includes goods, services, rights, & interests "in which contracts for future delivery are presently or in the future dealt in." So there doesn't have to be a derivatives market yet, just a theoretical future one.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @philbbelanger @bitjefe @cburniske @CFTC @TheJusticeDept Here's a slide deck from the Futures Industry Association with more details on market manipulation under the CEA as of 2019, if you want to dig into the law. There's a section on differentiating manipulation versus legitimate conduct: https://t.co/rwR1wm87pm

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@BlockEnthusiast @Mariandipietra DeFi is a vague & badly defined term. No doubt.

I'd argue the opposite, that DeFi means self-custodial financial activity without reliance on trusted third parties.

Bitcoin allows value transfer & storage.

Other DeFi protocols seek to allow more complex activity.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
I totally get the skepticism of the jaded bitcoiner who watched the rise & fall of dumb idea (blockchain, not bitcoin!) after dumb idea (ICOs!) after dumb & overtly fraudulent idea (Bitconnect!).

DeFi isn't all that. Bitcoin *is* DeFi.

We're just trying to go one step further.

name: Jake Chervinsky

Yield farming is a speculative, unsustainable second-order effect.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ZachSmolinski @HatHatHatHa Right, but game-theoretic incentive design is why we're here. We know the game theory underlying Bitcoin works. We're still collecting data on formal governance.

There was a prisoner's dilemma here where YAM holders could've bailed out, & a logistics problem. Both worked out.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@HatHatHatHa @ZachSmolinski Fair & you won't catch me defending the fundamentals of the project; I don't see the point of the elastic supply model.

But also to be fair to the project team, they were very clear that the code was an unaudited "minimum viable monetary experiment." The mania was not by design.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @ZachSmolinski @HatHatHatHa I agree it's not a revolutionary leap forward, but the subject is if decentralized governance by token vote is efficient & incentive-aligned enough for complex financial protocols; here, the speed not only of coordinating the vote but the community's very emergence is noteworthy.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @stephendpalley Agree to disagree, then.

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@stephendpalley Hi.

Is it possible to think YAMs were wildly overvalued & that the core mechanic of elastic supply is senseless . . .

. . . while also thinking the successful exercise of coordinating global action by a dispersed two-day-old community has some value?

Or is that too nuanced?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@ZachSmolinski Here's mine. Not that we didn't know coordination by vote was possible before, or that this single data point validates the mechanism wholly, but there is value in observing the success of the experiment (as there would've been if it had been a failure).
https://t.co/eTSfz6Iwsk

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@kryp_tos It's totally fine if you're only interested in ruthlessly trust-minimized, self-sovereign money -- Bitcoin is amazing! Nobody's forcing you to get involved in Ethereum.

But not everything risky is "irresponsible" and not everything you dislike is a "scam."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@evrythgcurrency @IvanOnTech A lot. I'd say the headline is a proof of concept for the model of distributing governance rights directly to protocol users; although unaffiliated, they were properly incentivized & capable of organizing quickly to solve a problem.

I'm sure others will have smarter takes, too.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@kryp_tos The launch post literally described this as a "minimum viable monetary experiment."

Everything in this space is still an experiment, by the way, Bitcoin included.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Karalhoin But nobody experimented with other people's money. People joined the experiment with their own money, fully aware (or capable of being fully aware) that the code was unaudited & without any promise of financial gain. That's as good as it gets. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @YourETHGirl @sassal0x Yes! And that's the point: when you have an unaffiliated community so vastly dispersed that collusion is impractical, they're game-theoretically incentivized to make economic decisions best for everyone, not unlike miners following consensus rules. That's the magic at play here.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
I went to sleep thinking how amazing it was that YAM, in just two days, spawned a novel global community that organized organically to win a complex coordination game.

I woke up to the bad news and my view hasn't changed one bit.

This was an extraordinary governance experiment.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@stephendpalley @eToroUS Okay, fair enough, we're disintermediating escrow agents. I'm cool with that.

Side note, I love this dynamic where you're touting the game-changing promise of smart contracts & I'm interrogating you with skepticism. Nice change of pace. ü§£

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @stephendpalley @eToroUS But isn't the exercise of discretion limited to determining if the condition is fulfilled, not whether to execute a transfer that depends on fulfillment? Assuming no solution to the oracle problem, how does a smart contract reduce trust? Do escrow agents simply refuse to perform?

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @stephendpalley @eToroUS This is a minor improvement but I'm not sure it's game-changing. If you're already trusting a third party to report on the fulfillment of a condition, it's not a big leap to place funds in escrow with a third party who executes the transfer. That doesn't require a smart contract.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@BitcoinTina @gladstein I agree about the focus on services, and there's no lending in DeFi. Few understand this (seriously).

DeFi creates interest rates with overcollateralized borrowing, not credit-based lending, which can't be done purely on-chain. It was a mistake for people to call this "lending."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @bitcoinomnivore @gladstein You do if you want to conduct financial activity more complex than send & receive. Those may be most important, but they're not enough to support an economy. DeFi's goal is to enable a full range of peer-to-peer financial services so BTC can do more than store & transfer value.

name: Jake Chervinsky

tweet: @zndtoshi I'm saying I'll change my opinion if it turns out DeFi can't safely & effectively automate any financial services more complex than send & receive, which Bitcoin already does just fine on its own; if the added complexity inherently requires reliance on trusted third parties.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@zndtoshi DeFi differs from ICOs & IEOs as it isn't a fundraising scheme. Run away from anyone selling tokens on the promise of building a protocol.

Not everything can be decentralized. There may be limits that make DeFi inherently inferior to CeFi in terms of efficiency & functionality.

name: Jake Chervinsky

I think bitcoin is the best money in the world.

Today, bitcoin depends on custodial intermediaries for financial services beyond send & receive.

These trusted third parties are security holes.

Replacing legacy banks with bitcoin banks isn't enough.

Thus, DeFi.

name: Jake Chervinsky

Yelling "scam!" at everything you don't like does more harm than good.

We can argue merits without the hyperbole.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@JordanLzG @Gargant34260060 @CamiRusso Okay, I should've said overcollateralized borrowing positions in permissionless, creditless peer-to-pool DeFi protocols that function on free market liquidation mechanisms aren't loans.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @StewartalsopIII I think I need to start by writing this up, but then maybe.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@StaniKulechov @shvandrew @CamiRusso "Collateral" is a term of art with a very specific definition that explicitly does not include an unsecured promise to repay debt based on a history of trustworthiness.

It's very important that we not confuse or mislead people by conflating secured debt with unsecured credit.

name: Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @shvandrew @CamiRusso But there's nothing "decentralized" about a contract between two specified parties that happens to be recorded on-chain.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Gargant34260060 @CamiRusso True, which is why overcollateralized borrowing positions fundamentally *are not* loans.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@shvandrew @CamiRusso That's not what "collateral" means.

Collateral is specific property pledged as a security interest for the repayment of debt, which can be seized in the event of default.

Collateral creates a "secured debt."

A promise to repay with no collateral is "unsecured debt."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@CamiRusso How is this different from someone borrowing from the protocol, sending someone else what they borrowed, & trusting they'll get paid back?

This is not "DeFi."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@QWQiao It's not uncollateralized, it's just collateralized by someone else.

The "credit" piece is no different than legacy finance, except that the contract is recorded on-chain (which you can do with any transaction).

name: Jake Chervinsky

That's why I get worried when I see calls for a "DeFi boom" or the like.

It's hard enough for people who live & breathe crypto to keep up with the blazing pace of development, & at least we know where to find reliable info.

The chance of newcomers making bad decisions is high.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
There's something genuinely exciting happening here: the creation of natively digital assets with novel, unique, & diverse (if experimental) properties.

But if we've learned anything in crypto, it's that real innovation begets flawed imitation, which begets fraudulent schemes.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
I have the same problem with "personal tokens."

Some are just interesting & harmless experiments by people playing with new tech. Others are blatant attempts to raise money by selling investment contracts, reminiscent of ICOs.

The former suffers by association with the latter.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
I'm suspicious of describing "DeFi tokens" as a category.

These tokens have vastly different characteristics & pose varied & complex risks, as do their underlying protocols.

Calling them all "DeFi tokens" both legitimizes the terrible projects & undermines the space as a whole.

tweet: @tarunchitra @alexhevans Interesting, I'll take a look & maybe we can discuss at some point. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@tarunchitra @alexhevans Right, but instant/perfect liquidation is a unique feature of a permissionless/overcollateralized borrowing protocol.

MBS make mortgages liquid, but a mortgage is just a right to seize illiquid collateral; it isn't comparable to a liquid digital asset that is collateral itself.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @tarunchitra @alexhevans I appreciate the analogy, but there's a lot more to say here about the differences between mortgage foreclosure vs. on-chain liquidation of prepaid, locked assets that make overcollateralized borrowing positions fundamentally different from MBS. (But you knew I'd say that.)

Among them, the need for optionality & flexibility, & to avoid the hubris of thinking we can achieve perfection without experimentation.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
8/ Within a few years of taking office, Washington decided he *must* create a cabinet, knowing full well that the Constitution didn't authorize it & the framers hadn't wanted it.

It's a remarkable tale of an extraordinary leader who set precedent that survived hundreds of years.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
7/ George Washington -- already an American hero & so certain to become the nation's first president that the position was basically designed for him -- tried his best to use only these two methods to obtain advice.

Neither was sufficient to meet the actual needs of governance.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
6/ As ratified, the Constitution gave the President only two ways to obtain advice on critical issues:

- written opinions from the department secretaries, or
- in-person advice from the Senate while in session

Both ensured the source of advice would be recorded & known to all.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
5/ So how did we end up with a cabinet anyway?

üö®shill alertüö®

You'll have to buy the book to get the whole story, which is fascinatingly & beautifully written by @lmchervinsky.

But in short, it turned out that the framers' governance model didn't survive contact with reality.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
4/ Suspicious of the British privy council's influence over the King, the framers were concerned that a cabinet would obscure responsibility for decision-making in the executive branch.

An early draft of the Constitution included a cabinet. It was removed in the 1787 Convention.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
3/ Despite its pivotal role in federal governance for centuries, the cabinet is not authorized or even addressed in the Constitution.

This was not mere oversight. The framers of the Constitution considered & *explicitly rejected* proposals to establish an executive cabinet.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
2/ The cabinet includes the Vice-President & the heads of all fifteen executive departments. It gathers often to advise the President on critical issues of national concern.

These days we take the cabinet for granted, assuming it's a standard segment of the bureaucracy.

Not so.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
1/ We talk a lot about governance in crypto: whether it exists, how much we need, & what we can do better than ever.

We can learn a lot from one of the best examples in history: the creation of the executive cabinet.

Disclosure: my wife wrote this! üòÉüëá
https://t.co/LJpbWxcijj

name: Jake Chervinsky

If we have to beat this with herd immunity -- 50% are infected & recover -- then over 1 million may die.

name: Jake Chervinsky

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @powers_chris They're overcollateralized but still depend on trust, e.g., that the homeowner won't depreciate the home / the fairly illiquid real estate market won't crash / etc. before the lender can foreclose through judicial process. Fundamentally different from a cryptonative system.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @iamtexture Trust minimization & permissionlessness are core elements of decentralization, without which there's basically no point to any of this. If you want to loan money on the basis of trust / the ability to enforce a judgment against extrinsic assets, a blockchain does nothing for you.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @powers_chris Home equity loans are definitely loans, but they aren't remotely trust-minimized overcollateralized borrowing positions.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @hurshidn @DonRasmusson ü§£

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @devilninja777 Sure, but calling that a "loan" doesn't make much sense, particularly if the transaction is designed to unwind before it becomes insolvent without any additional input from you.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: The central goal of DeFi is to disintermediate as much of the financial system as possible, but there may be a limit. Just as we imagine the existence of "bitcoin banks," which would be reduced to a shadow of today's megabanks, we can imagine the survival of credit-based lenders.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: I basically agree with this (minus the fraud bit). Credit-based lending requires trust & identity, which are incompatible with DeFi. What we have now is overcollateralized borrowing, a different type of financial activity where trust can be minimized. DeFi lending doesn't exist.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @lex_node @bonowskiz üíØ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @lex_node @bonowskiz Also, undercollateralization isn't the only problem with tokens representing off-chain assets. There's also the unknown cost of enforcement in case the tokenholder needs to sue for control of the underlying asset. This is an unsolved (and maybe unsolvable) problem.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @RydesaurusRex I'm not up to speed on Blockstack, but I certainly agree that regulation / disclosures can't cure every ill that inflicts capital markets. Even fully compliant public companies play games with, e.g., their accounting practices. But still, some disclosures are better than none.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
The uninformed securities law hot take of the day is that a "safe harbor" exemption is equivalent to "no rules for scammers."

The opposite is true. Scammers won't bother trying to qualify for a safe harbor. Projects that comply would be more credible & transparent than the rest.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @Frances_Coppola The point is to incentivize token issuers to make *more* disclosures about their projects instead of dodging the securities laws altogether on the basis of uncertainty re: Howey. Scammers won't bother trying to qualify. Issuers that do will be more credible than the rest.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @IOTArchy At least you know I'm calling it like I see it! üòâ

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: I fully support this concept. The disclosures required to qualify for the safe harbor are much better tailored to digital tokens than the traditional regime. The language may need some tweaks, but overall this is a step in the right direction. Bravo, @HesterPeirce!

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @sudogene @juthica Right, but if you try sending money to the wrong person or place, you'll likely get flagged for review by their compliance team. These systems are designed to catch all sorts of suspicious activity (e.g., "structuring," a series of small transactions designed to evade detection).

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @juthica To an extent, sure, but you can't provide real privacy while also doing suspicious activity monitoring, keeping CDD info up to date, performing regular audits, etc. These are all required under the BSA.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @sudogene @juthica AML compliance is "risk-based," meaning customer due diligence should be updated as frequently as necessary to match risk, but not more. But the bigger issue isn't "re-KYC'ing" customers -- it's transaction monitoring, diligence on transactions, reporting, audit, etc.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @juthica I see where you're coming from, but KYC isn't a one-time requirement -- a regulated financial institution can't just do it "upfront" and then ignore customers' transactions thereafter. In general, AML compliance and financial privacy are fundamentally opposing forces.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
Even if Ripple wins its motion to dismiss & has the whole class action thrown out, it won't mean much for XRP.

The big & interesting question is if XRP was (or is) a security. Ripple's motion didn't ask that question, so dismissal won't answer it -- just defer it to another day.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @zerpenator @galgitron @sentosumosaba @Kevin_Cage_ @MoonLamboio The point being, it's pretty much never right to assume that a potential target of an SEC enforcement action is safe from prosecution thanks to the statute of limitations.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
@zerpenator @galgitron @sentosumosaba @Kevin_Cage_ @MoonLamboio No, tolling agreements are kept confidential as part of the SEC's investigation, the mere existence of which is not publicly known until after it's completed.
https://t.co/aSb6eWHVR4

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @galgitron @zerpenator @sentosumosaba @Kevin_Cage_ @MoonLamboio I should add, if the SEC is investigating a case and the filing deadline is approaching, they can ask a target to sign a "tolling agreement" extending the limitations period (on threat of an enforcement action). Pretty much everyone agrees. I have no idea if Ripple has done this.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @galgitron @zerpenator @sentosumosaba @Kevin_Cage_ @MoonLamboio Unlike private citizens, who are subject to a three-year statute of repose for '33 Act claims, the SEC has a five-year statute of limitations for most enforcement actions (and none at all for others).

tweet: @spencernoon Yes, although the two are closely related, if not essentially the same thing.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @dibellrang Probably not, since the case isn't actually about whether XRP is a security *today* but rather whether it was a security during the relevant time period of the alleged offenses (mostly in 2017). Anything that happened after that time period likely won't impact the case.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @naq2323 @BankXRP The timeline for class actions is particularly long. We'd have to get through class certification and summary judgment before even thinking about trial. That could be several years, especially if Ripple keeps up its strategy of "delay, delay, delay."

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @naq2323 @BankXRP That depends how busy Judge Hamilton's docket is. Notice that she has four other motions set for hearings at the same time tomorrow. name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @buzimowicz No, this is just a "proposed order" submitted by the plaintiff, which is required under the court's local rules. You'll find a proposed order submitted by Ripple with the opposite ruling as well. Judges can sign a proposed order if they want, but rarely do for motions to dismiss.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
In the XRP securities class action, oral argument on Ripple's motion to dismiss is scheduled for 9 am PT tomorrow.

MTDs like this are usually resolved by written order weeks or months after oral argument. Unless Judge Hamilton tips her hand, we likely won't learn anything new.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet:
I'm not big on price predictions, but this seems likely:

- bitcoin halving occurs
- number goes up significantly (before or after)
- stock-to-flow proponents claim victory
- detractors claim correlation & cite confounding variables
- the argument goes on
- rinse & repeat in 2024

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: @d_eleye I don't mean to pass judgment on Faegre Baker Daniels or this specific lawsuit, but it should be (and is) possible to give helpful & constructive advice on difficult or unsolved problems without committing malpractice. With some exceptions, the AmLaw 100 doesn't even want to try.

name: Jake Chervinsky
tweet: Many private lawyers -- especially those in biglaw -- are more concerned about getting hit with a malpractice suit like this one than anything else. The result is perverse: these so-called "top" firms give the least attention to industries facing the toughest regulatory issues.
